4083: The wealthy don't work, they have other people work for them.
4084: He has weathered countless storms and steered many ships safely to harbours. Will his luck persist?
4085: Bitten by the travel bug, nothing and no one can stop her from traveling the world.
4086: A bright young journalist once determined to reveal truth, now struggling with the realities of his job.
4087: Your sister Hannah, whom you left behind with your family and the business. She was never quite in father's favour like you were.
4088: Keep family and friends close. They give us purpose, they guide us. Please take this to some like-minded friends of mine.'
4089: Potatoes are poisonous was the rumour at afternoon tea. I doubt it, but dreadful if true! Perhaps it's worth investigation?'
4090: ...then all proceeds to schedule- Oh, hello my young acquaintance. I presently have need of some dynamite, for a household project.'
4091: Earl Smedley is a danger to our poor vulnerable Queen! Twelve years ago he crushed my cat beneath his Landau. I have never forgotten.'
4092: "I noticed a ship pretending to be a trading ship, then attacking other ships. Someone has to take care of it before it can cause even more trouble. Would you be so kind?"
4093: "A pirate ship connected to my niece is in trouble. While I don't support what they do, most of them had everything taken away and they were forced down this path, just like she was. I simply cannot ignore family in need."
4094: A plot against our frail young monarch! The ship may seem proper, but do not let yourself be fooled. Kill the snake, and secure our Queen a surer destiny.'
4096: "Someone found the necklace I lost years ago, but now their ship sank. It was a gift from my brother when I was young. An old woman like myself can have a strong sentimental attachment to things bringing back good memories."
4097: Cousin Mary cut her visit short after seeing the feline predator enclosures! Maybe she ate something foul ...? Would you bring her home?'
4098: "I saw an unfortunate ship get destroyed by a mysterious ship earlier, it looked like it belonged to those Pyphoreans. Seeing these wreckages reminds me of the tragedy, could you remove them dear?"
4099: "A visiting ship forgot some cargo in my harbour. Would you be so kind to pick up and bring it to them my dear?"
4105: Let's play a game. A visitor ship will pass through the area soon. I will attack it, and you must defend it. I don't see you succeeding, but surprise me!
4106: Her Majesty commends you to those of us on the royal council. It can only serve to increase that trust then, for her to see us sail together, and presume I also trust you.'
4107: Some innocent merchants have had a bit of bother. Could you guide them to my harbour, where they will be quite safe?'
4108: Viscount Foxweasel has borne a grudge ever since I smothered him in manure at public school initiation. He plans to sink my exhibition of recent carvings. Can you ensure it arrives intact?'
4109: The Maya expedition was a success, but rough seas have deposited one of Her Majesty's treasures en route. She would be most indebted if you could recover it.'
4111: They are not traditionally a sailing nation you see, the hill-dwellers. Lost last time, and the time before that. Perhaps you can save us, and guide them in?'
4113: You know, the fools stole my least interesting sculptures! Still I'd rather such naive carvings weren't inflicted upon the general public!'
4114: "I am really bored, so I thought it would be fun to send one of my strongest ships into enemy waters and watch the show. I will hold you responsible if my ship somehow sinks. "
4115: I can barely believe it, my own advisor stole from our destitute fund! He needs to learn what loss means, even if it means sinking his prized ship.'
4116: "A ship sank in the area. I got a ship ready to bring the castaways to safety, just drop them off there."
4124: The Duchess of Powys can be quite lemony with me, but perhaps you could whizz by and explain the jolly mix-up - vigilant times, the sinking of her barge, etc.'
4125: Her Majesty received an alarming missive over second breakfast. Threats to 'undermine' her authority. Perhaps you could bring the matter to a peaceful climax?'
4126: Shocking to hear rumours of dissidents nearby. Such a brazen threat to our inexperienced Queen. Play the patriot and stamp out the growing fire.'
4128:
A person who has evidence, who can testify, who has certain knowledge (scientist etc).

Can be someone who helped them, has to be escorted out safely - Or someone who has to be escorted in safely

Reason for player involvement: don't draw additional attention with royal escort
4129:
Archie needs the players help to escort an expedition he is either about to send out, or that is returning.

The expedition was to gather new types of wood he heard awesome rumors about, in an attempt to find the ultimate carving wood.

However, jealous competitors got word of it too, they might want to sabotage. So the player gets asked to help out.
4130:
Hunt wants the player to escort a scientist who just made a "great discovery", the greatest discovery. Really. She will be able to save humanity.

She is afraid others might want to stop this or steal the knowledge/ideas, so asks for an escort just in case (do we spawn attackers?)

Maybe royale attackers? Or is this too direct?

She portrays the mission as "for the good of humanity", can't imagine anyone wanting to interfere - then there are a lot of attackers, makes the player wonder if intentions are good.
4131: I believe in slow penance for wrongdoers - counting grain, for example. You see, if even small crimes go unpunished, one's whole world may go to seed.'
6704: I can't bear to know my people feel the chill. All I can think of is drapes for the windows. To keep from them the bitter winter soon to come.'

9541: "While Jean and I have a very different approach, we share a goal in which we face a common enemy. If he does well, it benefits the movement as well."
9542: I have three ships ready to set out and help the people from a recently liberated piece of land. La Corona did not even provide them enough food or good clothes. I cannot wait to take action against these animals, but we have to be patient.
9543: The enemy is using the latest technology, and we have to adapt if we want to keep up. We have been offered engineering help, but we lack the required materials.
9544: La Corona are way out of line torturing and killing local people. Even though we can't openly act, they have to be stopped, I can't bare seeing this.
9545: I have reports coming in of a group of colonial war ships entering the region. I don't know what they are up to, but last time we did not act, things got nasty. I learned the hard way that in these situations its either them or us.
9546: George Smith, a man I deeply respect for his actions, recently helped us out by sending a scout ship. He successfully identified La Corona were delivering weapons. Please make sure his efforts are not in vain.
9547: I am very much against it, but I am afraid not giving in to the current request to take action against an La Corona ship visiting us, will cause internal conflict or even a division. One united movement will be required to win this battle.
9548: Bente Jorgensen has her heart in the right place. She came here to help as soon as she heard of the situation. However, the poor thing has no idea what she is getting herself into. I don't want her to get involved.
9549: The empire has been helping us out in secret. Another ship with supplies will soon arrive again, but La Corona have stepped up their presence in the area. I am afraid it will not reach us.
9550: Bad reputation. Parties located here are not friendly with you.
9551: Good reputation. Parties located here are friendly with you.
9552: An important, secret weapon delivery got disturbed by an inspection. The ones helping us were forced to drop the cargo overboard to not get into trouble themselves. Luckily I got word of the location.
9553: What is happening here in the region bothers me, more than you can imagine. But engaging in a battle we cannot yet win is not the way to go. These members of the movement tried and failed.
9554: I heard disturbing news from my family. They are in need of medical supplies which they are not getting. I have some ready, including a letter for them, and arranged a good friend who is willing to head there, but she cannot be seen near my harbour.
9555: Sometimes these waters can catch ships by surprise. In this case, I saw a Corona ship get wrecked. I want to have the wreckages of the ship analyzed to understand what we are currently up against.
9556: La Corona complicate everything. These pigs think they own everything, even the region's waters. Just the other day they halted my shipment of trading supplies, and took it all. I arranged the next shipment to be dropped at a designated map point, so this won't happen again.
9557: Hannah is relieved, and thinks Madame Kahina may know more of your father's things.
9558: Hannah would like help with a family matter.
9559: There's a family matter, on which I feel I must speak.
9560: I am glad you found the ring, many of his other effects vanished in the aftermath. Perhaps Madame Kahina can help trace them?
9561: The Editor would like to use a photo of your shipyard for the newspaper.
9562: Your father's trinket may not have much material value, but I sense there's more to it than that.
9563: The Editor is impressed about the great composition of the photo.
9564: This ring embodies the present; a serpent chasing its tail. Your father's child, you'll only break the cycle by escaping yourself.
9565: Finally, your first shipyard! What better news to open the first issue of your city's newspaper? The Editor asks that you take a picture of it, one that every man and woman in Ditchwater will see.
9566: Through these lenses the future manifests...first in darkness; an angry spark - then riots of flame!

9568: Save these poor souls from shipwreck, and prove that like father, we deserve their loyal support!

9571: Hannah is dismayed the cries of your shipwrecked followers were allowed to go unheard.

9674: I heard you are going to set on your first expedition soon! How exciting! I am also preparing an expedition actually, and I need some timber to have the damage on my ship repaired. I can't risk sending out a damaged ship with so many lives on board.
9675: I am glad to see you are doing so well! That ship should really help you. Right now you could use it to perform a good deed. I noticed a ship lose cargo just now, go and help them!
9676: Even though you faced some rejection, don't feel down! You just have to stay positive and keep trying. What always helps me cheer up is helping others, maybe it works for you too. You could help out the orphanage!
9677: So your father knew Isabel Sarmento too? I really look up to her and how she does everything she can to fight for the rights of the people. I prepared a ship to help, and I want to make sure it leaves safely.
9678: All this talk about social status. Although my advisors might care about these things, nothing changes for me, I always liked you. In fact, why don't we go for some sailing together, right now?
9704: All this talk about social status and what it means. Do you know what it really means? Absolutely nothing, all humans are useless creatures. I will let you experience how it means nothing first hand. I marked two ships of owners of different social status.
9705: They turned you down, so what. You know, screw them, when I feel down, blowing things up makes me usually feel better. Why not get back at them while you are at it? Sink one of their deliveries, that should hurt them.
9706: Isabel Sarmento huh, I don't care too much about what she wants and all that, but anyone fighting those Corona pigs gets my support. I have some unfinished business with them, so I will send a ship her way.
9733: So now you got a ship huh? I bet you couldn't even deliver wood to my harbour. I heard some rumors of how useless you are, and I am starting to think they might be true.
9734: Oh? So you really managed to do something right. It still doesn't prove much, though. You will need to do a lot more to earn the respect of people like myself. You can start by bringing me some more materials.
9735: I am not surprised people don't want to deal with you, you have no reputation to prove yourself after all. You should be thankful I am willing to give you work. Speaking of which, go pick up a delivery for me.
9736: The New World seems to be the talk of the day. I am sending a ship there too, and see what sort of beneficial deals I can get out of the locals. But some ex-trading partners of mine have been annoying me, so you are responsible for the safety of my ship.
9739: The strength of the movement will only increase as we expand our territory. I have my eyes set on certain pieces of land, belonging to private owners. I will need a good amount of gold to compensate them.
9744: La Corona started rapidly construction a huge bridge. This bridge means they have a much stronger position, preventing it is our top priority. I already noticed several ships carrying materials, those are easy targets.
9745: I sent out a ship to gather information on La Corona and what their next move might be. I got word the ship returned with crucial information, and we can't afford to have it travel unguarded.
9746: We managed to get these children away from La Corona. My harbor has been a safe haven for them, but they are still in the middle of conflict. They will travel to a safer place with this ship, and I want to ensure their safe leave.
9748: Oh, you've been preparing for an expedition? How exciting! In fact, I'm itching to set out again, but my ships need urgent repairs. Help a fellow pioneer in need?
9749: The faster we're done, the sooner we can set out!
9752: Thank you, fellow traveler! I'll steer clear of coral reefs this time.
9754: Society is unforgiving with what to do and not do ... but it is most unforgiving to the poor and orphaned. Us oddballs can still help!
9755: Don't let the sneering get you down!
9756: The children are overjoyed! People are wrong about you.
9758: It must be wonderful to be back on a ship! Now you can help people out even better - I heard a trader lost cargo just close to you!
9759: A ship is indispensable when helping people!
9760: You should have seen the look on the trader's face!
9762: So you've heard of Isabel, the dreamy rebel leader? I so want to support her, can you escort my ship of supplies to her?
9764: I'm sure this will bring the movement closer to victory!
9766: My advisors finally came around to you, proclaiming things about standing ... but I've always liked you! Do you want to escape the fuss on a sailing trip?
9767: I just told my advisors I'd step out for some fresh air!
9768: And we didn't even need any standing for a lovely trip!
9770: Where did you get a ship?! You look more like a deck-scrubber to me. Or can you disprove society rumours you're a worthless parasite?
9771: A ship, how?! The least you can do is serve me with it.
9772: Amazing, you delivered wood. We're all so proud of you and your ship.
9773: The rumour is true, you have no use.
9774: Independent Isabel makes exploitation of her people so hard, there must be something I can get them hooked on...
9775: Sarmento's Movement must be prone to vice, get to it!
9776: They drown in schnapps, and I in money!
9778: Surprised they reject you? A squit with not a gnat's cummerbund of reputability? Here's the sort of menial labour you were born to do...
9780: Down on your shins and thank me.
9781: That's the last time I bother rejecting you!
9782: Finally risen up to sour the cream of decent society? Look after my rich friends, or I'll ensure you never live it down.
9783: Standing notwithstanding, you have it all to prove.
9784: Licking boots won't get you up the ladder, you know.
9785: Society belches violently in your direction.
9786: Isabel Sarmento is a simpering wisp. She needs fattening up if she is to play scapegoat on feast day. The day La Corona are massacred.
9787: Isabel has need of our indulgence...
9788: The turkey is plump, soon the feast can begin!
9789: Perhaps you want to be sacrificed instead?
9790: Proud of your standing, ehh, but what does it mean? A poor ship, an aristocrat ship. Destroy both, then come tell me how it help the aristocrats, ehh?
9791: Show me, poor or rich, that they are equal in death.
9792: Wolves are free from the leash to kill as they please.
9793: Perhaps I can appreciate standing... on your tongue.
9794: Rejection is your prison, but destruction the key to freedom. Realise violence, and imagine it is them you destroy.
9796: Yes. Life is rejection, so reject life.
9797: You have a sordid fetish for rejection.
9801: Pearls, I love threading them. However, my current supplier was acting up, so I told him that he is no longer needed. I want to show him my words have meaning, and that he truly is instantly replaceable.
9802: Maintaining social contacts and status is very important, something you will learn at some point. For this reason I don't want to disappoint an old client, although I don't do these things myself anymore.
9803: Suhail Salim Rostamina, a Sheikh with great power and influence is visiting the region. We did some business before, but I want to further invest and refresh his memory. Make sure to mention Madame Kahina sent you!
9804: I couldn't explain you why exactly, but an eerie feeling has been bothering me ever since this morning. I can't help but feel something bad is about to happen.
9805: Looks like I have run out of Champagne. Don't you sometimes wonder how things would look if you made a different decision somewhere in the past? It's so fascinating how decisions result in chains of irreversible consequences.
9806: Customers repeatedly ask me for these Pocket Watches. I don't exactly find them exotic, but seems that I might be able to make good money with them. I would like to try a sample batch.
9807: My next shipment will not be here for a while, and some of my stocks completely depleted. It would be foolish not to take money when I have the possibility to do so.
9808: An old friend in need reached out to me. He made a huge mistake; told the client it was done without confirming himself. Turns out the target is alive and well, here in the Old World. If the client finds out it could cost him his live.
9809: Under normal circumstances I would just feel sorry for these sad, petty criminals. but they decided to steal from one of my shipments this time around. If I would be dealing with it myself, I would cut off their hands.
9810: I recognized a ship as being part of the organization that once betrayed me. Its presence in the region might be a complete coincidence, but it might have come to track me down, a risk I am not willing to take.
9811: One could argue killing people is never a good thing, but I would say they are wrong. The jobs I took helped the world get rid of some terrible people. But this local assassin is only in it for the money, taking every job.
9812: Years ago I made a mistake and took a job I should not have. It left the wife and children of my target in a bad position. From time to time, I arrange an anonymous delivery for them, containing things they might need. It soothes me knowing they do well.
9813: You show up just at the right time. Perhaps a bit boring, but I have a small job for you. One crate of this client's purchase was accidentally left behind by the ship picking it up. I do miss the thrill of my old life in my moments like these.
9814: Someone I used to know is running from authorities. She needed to get rid of a few pieces of evidence, and notified me where she left them. I am afraid I have to provide them to the authorities, she should have been more careful.
9815: This client requested their purchase to be delivered to their ship rather than coming to pick them up. While small requests like these annoy me, take my word for it when I tell you the importance of gaining people's respect and keeping them close.
9816: I have always been a role-model citizen, so there is nothing to compensate for, but from time to time, I donate things I can miss so they end up with those needing them.
9817: Friends from back home are paying me a visit. These are the type of people at the very top of society, used to nothing but the best. They surely expect a proper escort.
9818: The side effect of providing exotic high-value wares is that it has the tendency to attract certain buyers. The kind that feels too important to travel without escort.
9819: I have a very expensive shipment coming in soon. The value is likely beyond what you can imagine. Point is, it is the kind of shipment one does not allow to travel unguarded.
9820: This lord claims he no longer purchases from me because he is too afraid of pirates to send his ships into the region. An excuse of course, but I knew how to deal with it. I offered him an escort, and guess who is buying again.

9914: I'll come down on you like a tonne of bricks' he used to say. Well let's see who has the last laugh, now we're all grown up eh?!'
9915: Alfred and Filbert are a lovely pair of shillings. Now, I couldn't remember if it were ten tonne or twenty owed. But being gents, they were quick to remind me it was thirty.'
9916: My latest trick is called 'The Devil's Vessel' a fearful extravaganza of sea-fire! Got a bit hot the first time...'specially for the crew, but its getting there, getting there...'
9917: A pocket watch I can guess your card,' is how the trick starts. Shame the cards they keep choosing are the hardest ones to find.'
9918: Asking for gold, I was sure it was the ghost, come for his due. Luckily it's only a brigand, and he gave his word it'd just be this once!'
9919: Lord Flattenflee and I had such a cultured chat, I think he loaded up one too many crates! Haha. I've got loads more, course...but I do need those materials.
9920: I get through quite a few stage assistants...I mean, you know, they leave. Can't take the city lights, the glamour. P'haps if they looked the part, they'd feel the part?'

9930: Why'd he have to shout out how its done?! Time that bully Astronomo got a huge kick up the interior - it's what mum wouldda done.'
9931: I'm caught between a frog and a toad! Board want off with a dangerous geezer. I'm like the David to his Goliath, but can I leave all that glory to you?'
9932: I may be amazingly powerful, but I'm hardly cruel. Take this darkness off me 'ands, you'll get a reward. Just don't tell the board, alright?'
9933: Whoopsiedaisies, some crates fell into the ocean when I was moving them on my docks. My mom would always tell me to keep things clean. I don't even recall what's in the boxes, so you can keep them for your efforts.
9934: Magic is truly underappreciated. Was just performing in front of the board during the trip, and out of the blue, one ofthem grabs my entire magic box and throws it overboard. He is lucky I am so calm and let it slide just like that.
9935: I was instructed to not look in these boxes, so I will respect their privacy. I just don't understand why the board wants me to store them, they have warehouses too. I also don't get this whole secret drop off thing, they could just bring them here.
9936: Heard of some boxes floating out in the ocean. I tell ya, never underestimate what one might leave floating around. Get them before someone else does, this is Willie's deserved little moment of luck after all this misfortune.
9937: GO AWAY! No no, not you, I was talking to the ghost. I heard one can order a ghost to leave. Salt tends to keep them away too. I ordered a few crates, and even personally secured the shipment, but the ghost threw them overboard!
9938: If you ever want to get business advice from me, I might consider it. Just got a wonderful discount on these goods with minor defects, the supplier just dropped the goods and notified me where, not sure why he didnt just bring them.
9939: You could learn from my networking skills. Met this lovely chap, big scar over his eye. He is so kind to offer and pick up the payment he accidentally forgot. He just needs an escort because he apparently has some enemies.
9940: I could swear I had it just a minute ago, where is my wand?! Good thing you are here, I refuse to travel alone without my wand, not as long as the ghost is out there.
9941: Let me tell you about The Amazing Willie. Helped the board without hesitation when they requested help. Problem is that Amazing Willie is now involved in this conflict, and the board won't help me. My ships get constantly attacked.
9942: I guess I should have read the contract more carefully before signing it. But you know what, I don't mind having to give my close trading partners a free escort with every purchase they make, they are quite lovely really.
9943: I feel it, he is coming for me, the ghost! I need your help getting back to my harbour. I know what I will do! I will head to the lower deck and think about how to work on my tricks while you be on the lookout for the ghost when he strikes.
9944: Last time my delivery of magic supplies got mysteriously attacked. Who would possibly want to do that? I perform for everyone I know, frequently, without them having to even ask or pay for it!

10059: Beryl wants to teach the player about her business and wants him to practice the most useful method to put pressure on a trading partner. 10060: Another trading partner tried to trick Beryl by sending her low quality material. They thinned gunpowder with some fake powder, but she managed to look through it. Now she asks you to bring them their 'payment'.
10061:
Beryl mentions an inspector just visited her by surprise and got to see some things he should not have seen. It is of high importance this information does not get out.

I will absolutely not go to prison.
10062: They say piracy is in decline, and sadly, this is true. Unfortunate for local pirates like Anne, and even more unfortunate for their business partners like me. Parties like Lady Vistash, hired to hunt pirates, don't help the case. It is about time to fight back.
10063: Trust is the cornerstone of business relations. Lord Malkov, regular buyer of mine, broke this very trust. Several crates disappeared from my warehouse during his latest visit. Needless to say, I have no interest in further dealing with Malkov, and punishment is at place.
10064: I have many enemies from whom I know what to expect, the problem is unexpected enemies. Just last week I helped out a friend who needed mines. Today one of my ships reported spotting a mine on its route. I want to make sure these are not the mines I provided.
10065: Yesterday the ship I was on, ran into an unexpected inspection. While my crew was standing there I took it into my own hands to throw the crates of illegal goods overboard. I dodged the inspection, but I do need those goods, my buyers are waiting for them.
10066: Good money can be earned by dealing in smuggled alcholic drinks with high tax rates, such as rum, geneva and brandy. However, there is always a risk involved when selling them again. I received an unusually large order, which has my senses tingling,  and I am afraid of walking into an ambush.
10067: It is important to realize when someone you believe to be an ally, is your enemy. Bottom line: I am putting someone in my network who I don't trust to the test. I mentioned the route my ship full of riches will travel. If it gets attacked, I know enough, and you can interfere.
10068: Beryl wants to store her money somewhere safe and asks you to escort it out of the area. She does not trust the local bank.
10069: Beryl invited some of her friends to play cards and talk about business that they owe her. She wants you to "escort" them and to make sure that they aren't followed.

10521:
Dear Governor Bleakworth,

More of the traitor Samuel’s conspirators. Crimes and sentences as follows;

Ernest Sterling – Use of foul language – 16 years with hard labour.
Verity Goodheart – Impersonation – Transportation to the Antipodes.
Elias Noble – Writing a threatening letter – Life imprisonment
Honora Decent – Character assassination – Life imprisonment
The judge saw very well my view, that any lack of proof they conspired with a traitor was, in itself, evidence they hide something. All things considered, his verdict could have been far worse. While I am under no obligation to explain such details, I thought that as a fellow dispenser of justice, the facts of the case may be of interest to you.

Sincerely
Edvard Goode
(Edvard) Goode & Sons Ltd.

11171: WIP Text: This is the description text of the arctic event character.
11185: Farmers flock to join [Participants Current Profile CompanyName], hoping to prosper from the earth as they always have done.
11187: Engineers bring order to [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] chaos! Books, telescopes and chemical flasks under arm!
11189: Investors show their class at [Participants Current Profile CompanyName], tossing their money into the air, as if the bally stuff grew on trees.
11191: [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] settle first island. Many believe this first seed shall germinate into a towering money tree.
11193: [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] settle first island in Americas, sticky financial climate expected at first, but brighter later.
11196: New trade ship leaves [Game Profile Info Name] port with a mighty thirst for goods and commerce.
11198: Cutting edge warship leaves [Game Profile Info Name] port, certain to leave its enemies clinging to rocks.
11200: [Game Profile Info Name] is drafting an armada! To what purpose, only Neptune knows.
11202: Income no longer negative for [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] say delighted accountants.
11204: [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] bounce off the ropes of bankruptcy, their accounts no longer overdrawn.
11206: Fire guts part of [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], locals rage at failure of local authority to act.
11208: Fire died out of its own accord in [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName]. 'Just like squalls what come'n'go,' impassive local says.
11210: Firemen do their service proud in [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName], let us never take their sacrifice for granted.
11212: Special action smothers any chance of further fire in [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName], taking the heat off local authority.
11214: Inferno utterly guts [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], 'this city is damned!' croaks broken local.
11216: Special measures save [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] from the ravages of staggering inferno.
11218: Those who said it was storm in a teacup, now complaining that their laps are burned.
11220: Administration fortunate that concerns of populous have subsided naturally. But for how long?
11222: Riotous spasm is quelled in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], local governor expresses relief that deterrents are working.
11224: Special provisions prevent spread of riot in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], corking shut bottle of discontent.
11226: Any relief that ugly revolution has ended is overshadowed by doubt of whether damaged city will ever be the same again.
11228: Crowds of furious demonstrators are convinced to leave the streets of [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] by well-organised authorities.
11230: Swift government intervention saves [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] from the otherwise unshakeable grip of revolution.
11232: Illness in [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName] abates, but leaves locality drained of life.
11234: As disease in [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName] fortunately abates - thank heavens - locals ascribe recovery to angels watching over them.
11236: As special measures taken to curb further infection succeed, there is now no longer any need to panic in [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName].
11238: Epidemic leaves [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] empty, 'It was medieval! The whole place with the mark on their door' says one who fled.
11240: [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] fit-as-a-fiddle again, residents declare [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] patron saint of the sick and infirm!
11242: Special measures ensure [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName] disease epidemic is neutralised at epicentre, and a triumph of modern medicine!
11244: World's fair foundations complete! [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] ready for global prominence!
11246: New World's Fair construction phase underway! Excitement builds across the globe!
11248: World's fair completion edges ever-nearer as significant phase of construction is finalised.
11250: Magnificent monument 'firmly on track' to have ribbon cut on expected date.
11252: Significant delays plague [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] in the construction of their centrepiece, amid fear they may be overreaching.
11254: Desperate concern for halted monument construction, which some already label a 'white elephant.'
11256: [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] construct sublime World's Fair venue, a feat only imaginable in the present century!
11270: Expedition finally underway, after months of careful planning. Crew have 'spring' in step says Captain, but for how long?
11272: Expedition achieves the unthinkable! 'We survived monsters, both real and imagined…' the proud Captain had begun, before we cut him off.
11274: Expedition goes terribly awry! Captain asked for interview, but all he could do was shake his head.
11290: With new Market trading in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], the settlement really sets out its stall.
11292: New Cabaret kicks [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] into life, with allure of its exotic experiences.
11294: New University founded in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], its benefit to society is surely academic.
11296: New Members Club taking memberships in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], naturally the doors won't be opened to just anyone...
11298: Bank opens first accounts in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], 'it's a credit to this city,' say local authority.
11300: New Fire Station bell rings in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], let the noble fight against this beastly flame commence!
11302: New Hospital now operating in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], located with surgical precision, so as to best relieve community.
11304: New Visitor Harbour in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], guaranteed to bring tourists to these shores in droves.
11306: New zoo intoxicates crowds in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] with animal aroma of the exotic. As to exact specimens, watch this space!
11308: New museum in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] among first institutions to open eyes of public to wider world.
11310: New extension for [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] zoo opens. Our correspondent observes, unsure if something roams there, or if it was actually empty.
11312: New museum wing drape falls in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], revealing something historic.

11316: On error occurred during savegame transfer (Error [Online FetchSavegameErrorCode])

11322: Slick new Oil Power Plant burns in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], greasing the wheels of progress.
11324: Bespoke Coal Harbour built in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], so boats may scuttle in and out.
11326: Bespoke Oil Harbour built in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], so boats may glide in and out.
11328: New Guild House crops up in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], gathering our shared production expertise under one roof.
11330: New Town Hall sprouts up in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], gathering our shared social expertise under one roof.
11332: New Harbour Office bobs to the surface in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], gathering shared naval expertise under one roof.
11334: New Steam Shipyard releases pressure in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], where more trade may now begin to funnel in.
11336: New Harbour Defences encrust [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], damning any enemy who dares try their luck.
11338: New Repair Crane unfolds in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], helping put damaged ships together again.
11340: New Loading Pier unboxed in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], lifting a weight off.
11342: New Fishery flaps into life in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], as residents become hooked on fish.
11344: New Framework Knitters stitched together in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], as remarkable story continues to unravel.
11346: New Brick Factory fires up [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], as island builds for the future.
11348: New Sailmaker breezes into [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], are ships too then on the horizon?
11350: Fresh Bakery rises in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], to leaven the mood on the island.
11352: New Workwear Factory in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], means employees everywhere no longer need mention the word trousers!
11354: New Weapons Factory means [Game Profile Info Name] has the competition firmly in its sights.
11356: New Brewery in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] brims with desire to quench the town thirst.
11358: New Window Factory in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] sure to be a smash.
11360: New Cannery opens in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], to quite a receptacle crowd.
11362: New Pocket Watch Factory sprung upon [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], and not a moment too soon.
11364: New Rum Distillery uncorked in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], to a lengthy drum roll.
11366: New Chocolate Factory unwrapped in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], to temper sticky cocoa craving.
11368: New Bicycle Factory now peddling in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], locals are pumped up.
11370: New Reinforced Concrete Factory keeps [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] in the mix with rivals.
11372: Flashy new Light Bulb Factory in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] sure to guide way to enlightenment.
11374: New Champagne Cellar pops open in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], to everyone's great surprise!
11376: New Fur Trader slinks into [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], read on for more complete coverage.
11378: Fresh Cigar Factory rolls up in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], demand is cut and dried.
11380: New Gramophone Factory whirrs into life in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName]. Just for the record, here's our correspondent's spin.
11382: New Heavy Weapon Factory in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] propels town to bleeding edge of warfare.
11384: New Jewellers brings sparkle to [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], or at least gives a nice ring to it.
11386: New Carriage Assembly Line starts up in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], investors not getting carried away.

12901: Sir Archibald Blake has informed you that your Uncle has officially registered your debt with the Queen, preventing you from acquiring a shipping license until it's settled. It is unclear how or when will this be though, since your Uncle seems most reluctant on letting you escape from his grasp.
12902: You have cleaned most of the island by now, but a few sturdier ruins remain. Luckily, you have workers living in your city now. They are skilled enough to take care of them and aid you in the finishing phases of making Ditchwater the perfect place to grow your new company.

12912: Wormways Prison— A first terrible night!
12913: My island, Prosperity, is sold. That is all I can puzzle of my arrest, and present circumstance, shackled between these cold grey walls. Tomorrow I resolve to make my case again to Mr. Bleakworth, who today so cruelly refused me a proper explanation. Now I must try to sleep, and can think of nothing but my poor Hannah, and the other, so far distant.
12914: Wormways Prison – Light through the bars.
12915:
With daybreak comes clarity. Prosperity was sold to the infamous rebel 'Sarmento' – and I must be the last to have heard of it! The Queen, the nation, is up in arms, that the jewel of the new world is lost!

The guards, from whom I heard all, thought me playing some trick! Yet it is I who am tricked; duped of my island by persons unknown! Although it can only be the same persons that came to me one ominous day, masked and embroidered with eldrich symbols. They pressed me towards a sale. But I shut the door hard I tell you, and bid them good-day!
12916: I have today begun the process of gathering evidence in my defence. Hannah was here, though they did not let her stay long. She gives me hope that a full and unmitigated pardon is possible. Years of loyalty count in my favour, but the very idea that I may have betrayed my Queen weighs heavily upon me. Even if the dark clouds of scandal pass, they may forever have damaged our family’s prospects.
12917: Wormways - A third night, and alas not the last.

12937:
Dear Governor Bleakworth,

More of the traitor Samuel’s conspirators. Crimes and sentences as follows;
12938:
Ernest Sterling
Use of foul language – 16 years with hard labour

Verity Goodheart
Impersonation – Transportation to the Antipodes

Elias Noble
Writing a threatening letter – Life imprisonment

Honora Decent
Character assassination – Life imprisonment
12939:
The judge saw very well my view, that any lack of proof they conspired with a traitor was, in itself, evidence they hide something. All things considered, his verdict could have been far worse. While I am under no obligation to explain such details, I thought that as a fellow dispenser of justice, the facts of the case may be of interest to you.

Sincerely,

14019: You will soon miss construction materials! Place a lumberjack's hut in the middle of a forest. It will produce wood regularly.
14020: Then, place a sawmill close to your lumberjack's hut, and make sure they have a road access. Once the wood delivered, the sawmill will convert it into planks.

14024: Your advisor suggests to regularly visit the traders.
14026: Your farmers are starting to be hungry! You should start producing fish. Fisheries can be built at the coast only.
14029: Hannah suggests that you expand the settlement and meet the demands of your employees.
14030: Your settlement is in place. Now you need to expand the city and meet the growing demands in food and clothing of your employees. If enough of them are satisfied and their housing is improved, you can expect new talents working for you, soon.

14035: The Framework Knitters will weave the wool to create the demanded clothes.

14038: Schnapps provides happiness and high taxes. You can produce some from potatoes.
14039: The schnapps maker will process the potatoes into schnapps.
14043: A farmer has access to all he needs. You can upgrade his housing by selecting the upgrade mode, then the chosen farmer house.
14045: Destroying another building might make your enermy surrender!

14062: Some see them as symbol of bad luck.
14063: There is no better companion for hunting.
14065: The fire risk is increasing with those wooden huts. A fire station is the only building that helps preventing and fighting incidents.
14066: Each production building requires a specific workforce. Make sure you always have enough of each.
14071: Bricks are a new construction material, but the clay pit needs to be placed on a pre-existing deposit. There must be one on the island.
14074: You can edit your newspaper front articles at every new edition. It can change your employees behaviour and happiness.
14076: Hannah is looking forward to the industrialization of your settlement.
14077: The new social class, the workers, is really fitting to factory work. Keep expanding your settlement and start the production of steel beams, as those are necessary materials to build powerful factories.

14092: Isabel encourages you to build a police station to arrest the Pyrphorian arsonists.
14093: You can now build a shipyard to construct your own ships! This is the only way to start exploring the world.
14094: Steel beams are the next construction material and mark the beginning of the industrialization. You'll need iron!
14100: Hannah is worrying about the latent workers movement.
14101: Hard factory work and child labor lead the workers to voice claims and complaints. If you don't want to enter an instability state, you should take care of your security and provide education.

14109: A jornalero is very grateful to you.

14143: Gasparov world fair design is complete, soon he will be able to show to the world his superior vision ... if only he gets glass.
14144: Monsieur l'Ambassadeur is visiting Gasparov island to decide on future investments, he must be entertained with the best champagne.
14145: Gasparov's personal orchestra refuse to play in the middle of the night to stimulate their master creative process. Phonograph will do to replace them.
14146: Sailors are partying and whoring for days in front of Gasparov island, this does not look great for visitors. Destroy them.
14147: Gasparov needs you to pick up a paradise bird a friend has captured for him. It will look great in the Golden salon.
14148: Gasparov wants to write his autobiography in the most manificient of leather book. Pick the leather and enluminures in the ship werkage.
14149: Despite disliking Old Nate, he has some interesting goods Gasparov ordered to ornate his city. Pick them up at his harbor.
14150: Freddy Chapin is invited to play at Gasparov gentlemen club tonight, the occasion for him to shine in front of la haute societé. Make sure nothing happens to him on the way.
14151: Gasparov has finished to work on the design of the Queen next palace. Bring it to Archibald safely.
14152: Gasparov has bought a marble statue in an aunction but other had their eyes on it. Protect it during its transportation.
14153: Following his shrink advice, Gasparov wants to take some fresh air and be taken on the high seas.
14154: Gasparov thinks his city is better than anything he has seen on the way, he wants to go back.

14156: Sarmento asks for your help in evacuating her headquarters.

14306: A firm alliance between proud nations is achieved! The new partnership is set to be of vast importance to the immediate, even long-term futures of both sides. The final deal was mooted and passed under the noses, and more importantly, pens of the diplomatic suits in record time—
14308: "The decision does not mean our ongoing relations need turn nasty," was the official statement on cancelled alliance with [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context ParticipantName], and "no reason" why "alliance wouldn't be possible again in the future."
14310: Key alliance breaks down! With former ally [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context ParticipantName] providing no answers, officials left to speculate the reason they withdrew support. It is unclear how this disappointing news has been received at the highest level.
14312: A profitable new partnership with [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context ParticipantName]! Our correspondent furnishes us with the latest figures, and trumpets the immediate economic gains from the deal.
14314: Future plans do not include trade with [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context ParticipantName], if the rumours are to be believed. Who benefits the most from the decision? More perspective on the economic landscape on page 12!
14316: [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context ParticipantName] severs trade ties in shock for local business! What might have been a fruitful relationship comes to cruelly to an end, as partner reneges on promises. Sharp decline in economy forecasted with steep-looking graphs on page 4.
14318: Peace at last! [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context ParticipantName] signs treaty! Ambassadors return from the negotiating table with olive branch, white doves rise to the skies, children skip gladly through meadows. The war is over! Let the colour return to our cheeks!
14320: A ceasefire has been agreed. Whether moved to act by the destruction, or the strategic value of a pause, matters not. Wounds can now be licked, the situation reappraised, and perhaps, peace may be contemplated. The leaders of forces on both sides are said to be content with the situation.
14322: "No," say Admirals as conflict resumes following a period of ceasefire. Navies muster, sailors polish their cannons, powder is poured from kegs as the parties re-enter the pugilist's ring for another round. When will this needless bloodshed cease?!
14325: The powers that be have elected to go to war! Recruitment has already begun, lives at stake to uphold our values, to preserve unity and order, to meet danger half-way with zealous alacrity. Time will tell if it is a choice founded on wisdom.
14327: [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context ParticipantName] declares war! Peace and humanity desert us, as Mephistophelian adversary rises from the depths to confront us! We can only trust in our bravest to fight back this nemesis, and drive ruination from our shores.
14329: An alliance has formed between two of our rivals. Speculation mounts as to what they may be up to. Of course, their intentions could be perfectly chivalrous, but while any doubt remains, speculation of the more ignoble variety shall no doubt stir in the pool.
14332: An alliance between our rivals has broken down. In the following days, rumour is likely to gather as to that which broke the spell between them. It is unknown for example, whether this development will be seen positively or negatively here. More to follow.
14334: New agreements reached among our neighbours this forenoon—more details in today's Foreign Diplomacy, Trade and Things You Should Care About But Won't column.
14336: A trade agreement between rival powers has been cancelled. It seems they no longer saw eye-to-eye on the subject. Whether boom of this minor diplomatic eruption will reach our shores, remains to be seen.
14338: A peace treaty between rivals overseas has finally been kissed with a seal. Perhaps this grand gesture can seed a future of peace and progress. Or perhaps such wimpish withdrawals are symptomatic of this too-liberal age!
14341: A truce has been established between our neighbours. Pious hearts, non-partisans, will be glad that for a time, the suffering does not have to continue. How long will empathy last? Hortense McGough remarks upon the situation from the place of amnesty.
14343: A ceasefire has ended between two of our neighbours, meaning that it cannot be long before the first shot rings out into the night, and their forces are on top of one another once again. Let us hope the same winds of war do not blow this way. Full report pages 31-37.
14346: Our neighbours have declared war on one another. An intercepted telegram confirmed the news, which many believe had been brewing for some time - now the line is crossed, the damn burst! No reason for us to react however - neutrals should dissemble and play dumb!
14348: Pirate nuisance return, disproving reports they had been wiped out! Hidden coves making motley, pestilential denizens of the black flag hard to sniff out. Let us hope it is only a matter of time before  these skeletons of the last century go under for good!
14350: Diplomatic relations with [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context ParticipantName] have "deteriorated" recently, say disgruntled ambassadors, as "consequence of innate differences between us". We hope importance of maintaining good relations with neighbours is not being overlooked.
14352: Relations with [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context ParticipantName] have improved recently, say jovial ambassadors! Glasses clinked, and trays of finely-wrought chocolate pralines did circulate, as improved standing with our counterparts called for celebration.
14354: Unhappiness can lead to riots. The police station is the only building that will help you restoring order.
14355: All animal farms require enclosures. You can build them by selecting the farm once placed. They need to be placed in the radius of the farm.
14357: Pollution from heavy industry reduces your employees happiness. You can check the pollution of your island in the attractiveness menu.
14358: You can already start the weapons production. That's essential to build military ships and buildings.
14359: It's better to prepare your defenses in case of attack. Military buildings can be placed at the coast to defend your harbor.
14362: Missing a certain fertility? Trade routes can easily be setup from this menu. This enables goods transportation between islands.
14363: Your workers houses are ready to be upgraded. If you do so, we will welcome a new social class in the city.
14364: Bente Jorgensen is a young heir of the Jorgensen Trust. She is a very friendly person, caring for those around her. She is excited about exotic things and doesn't like injustice.
14365: Princess Qing is a young and relatively unexperienced member of a foreign Imperial family. She doesn't know the local customs and reacts awkwardly sometimes. She is a peaceful person, loving art, poetry and beauty.
14366: Willie Wibblesock is a leader of his own young company, but overestimates himself sometimes. He is scared of a lot of things, believing that demons are haunting him. He has been bullied a lot in his past. He is a hobby magician.
14367: George Smith is not his real name. Having grown up as the son of an enslaved miner, he was able to flee slavery. Since then, he had multiple professions, growing as a kind, honest and rightful person. Fairness and honesty are his main virtues.
14368: Beryl O'Mara is a career criminal, having her very own moral code and taking risks or getting her hands dirty. She doesn't see the necessity to follow established rules if she has a higher goal.
14369: Artur Gasparov is a visionary, in pursuit of architectural and civic perfection. Inelegance infuriates him. He likes to make a good impression, but otherwise has little time for others. He seeks critical acclaim and prestige for his designs, and to build a legacy.
14370: Carl Leonard von Malching is a tycoon. He is always looking for his own advantage, without any moral constraints. Money is his main focus. He is jealous of everybody that he feels is some kind of superior to him.
14371: Alonso Gravez is a violent leader. Passionate, intimidating on one hand, charming on the other. He is very hard to read. He appears insane, instinctive and unpredictable. He makes decisions based on gut feelings and not strategic analysis.
14372: Admiral Vicente Silva is a quiet, calculating and insightful general. The military has prepared him for everything. He is self-confident with a strong sense of honour and prestige. He is a long range thinker who has deep insight into politics, and a very good leader.
14373: Lady Margaret Hunt is a soulfoul old lady. Being a member of the Hunt enterprises she is extremely resourceful. She is a woman who knows what she wants and how to get it. She has seen it all come and go and is very hard to impress or intimidate. While she seems very kind and nice, disappointing her might have severe consequences.
14374: Anne Harlow is a highborn woman who turned to piracy after her father's decapitation. She is charismatic with a strong personality. She deeply hates the Queen, seeking revenge and attacking everything that belongs to the new Queen and her supporters.
14375: Jean La Fortune is a highborn illegitimate son of a foreign prince. As such, he became a slave who lately climbed the social ladder. He became an iconig figure of civil rights and now wants to get rid of any form of superior authority.
14376: Hannah suggests to start exploring the world for exotic productions.
14377: With your first artisans in town, your city is now ready to build stronger ships to explore distant lands. If you can reach there, you'll be able to produce exotic, valuable goods to bring back to the Old World. An opportunity no company shall neglect.

14397: Some of your engineers enriched themselves until reaching the highest tier of the society. They will never agree to work, but they would surely invest in worldwide events like the World Fair. It is time to start building a monument, and prepare for the festivities.

This immense building is the perfect place to organize somptuous exhibitions where the greatest minds in the world would bring and showcase their latest inventions, discoveries and constructions. If you can successfully organize an event, you may have access to the most attractive items for your cultural buildings, and become the most attractive city in the world.

14421: Allies will follow you into war against other parties. If your ally goes to war, you will also be at war with your ally's enemy.

14424: In Peace you cannot attack each other.
14425: In War you can attack each others' ships and buildings.
14426: To start an Island War, destroy your enemy's buildings to make them lose morale until they surrender. Then you can take over the island.
14430: A new construction material is required. windows require sand from the coast.
14442: Tourism can be a great source of income when your attractiveness is high. You need a visitors harbor to allow visitors to come over.
14447: You can launch expeditions. Have a look at the world map to find your possible destinations.
14449: You also have an overview of currently available expeditions here.
14450: Don't forget to send a discovery expedition as soon as possible. Build a ship and send the discovery expedition from here.
14451: You discovered a new region! You can access it from the world map, then by selecting the new session.
14453: One clay pit provides enough clay for two brick factories; this is an information that you can determine by looking at the processing time of each building. For now, you should build a second brick factory to optimize your production.
14454: Select the harbor at the desired location to build it.
14455: All warehouses will share the same storage all over your island.
14457: If you are missing certain goods, like planks, select the good in the trading post menu and setup the import and amount; ships will regularly fetch your stocks to maintain the stock amount you fixed.
14458: You can also deal with pirates from the diplomacy menu. This is the place where you can establish trade rights.
14459: You can also deal with pirates from the diplomacy menu. This is the place where you can establish trade rights.
14460: Sir Archibald Blake represents the Queen. He always has some interesting items and goods for sale at his harbor.
14461: Isabel Sarmento is the representative of the Movement in the New World. She also trades at her harbor.
14462: Old Nate likes to salvage things here and there and reassemble them into new items. If you take part in events, this is where you can exchange your event money for unique, special rewards.
14463: Eli Bleakworth is the director of the jail. You can bail a prisonner at the harbor, he will thank you by serving for your company.
14464: Madame Kahina has access to the products of the world. This is where you can trade exotic goods, but for a high price...
14465: Bente Jorgensen is a young woman who is totally into animals. She inherited her family's company. As a rival, she will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with her through the diplomacy menu.
14466: Princess Qing is part of an eastern royal family. She runs her family company subsidiary in the Old World. As a rival, she will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with her through the diplomacy menu.
14467: Willie Wibblesock found a cursed treasure which enabled him to found his own company. As a rival, he will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with him through the diplomacy menu.
14468: George Smith is a deaf former miner who climbed the social ladder after receiving education from a noble and inheriting his company. As a rival, he will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with him through the diplomacy menu.
14469: Beryl O'Mara made herself with illegal deals and a strong charisma. Today she runs her own company, which looks more like a mafia organization. As a rival, she will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with her through the diplomacy menu.
14470: Carl Leonard von Malching is the last member of a ruined family who could make himself as a robber baron owning a big company. As a rival, he will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with him through the diplomacy menu.
14471: Artur Gasparov is an architecture lover who runs his own company for the sake of beauty building. As a rival, he will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with him through the diplomacy menu.
14472: Alonso Graves is a dangerous, not trustworthy war hero who betrayed his nation to command an army of rebel, which he organized as his own company. As a rival, he will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with him through the diplomacy menu.
14473: Admiral Vicente Silva is an admiral from another empire, fighting to conquer the lands in the Old World. As a rival, he will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with him through the diplomacy menu.
14474: Lady Margaret Hunt inherited her former husband's company. As a rival, she will expand just as you do. You can negotiate and interact with her through the diplomacy menu.
14475: La Fortune is a pirate from the New World, a fidel support to the Movement cause. He won't expand but hunt you down on the seas with his ships. You can still trade with him at his harbor, if he accepts...
14476: Anne Harlow is a pirate. No one knows where she comes from. She won't expand but hunt you down on the seas with her ships. You can still trade with her at her harbor, if she accepts...
14477: Link the excavation site to a warehouse to support it with resources.
14479: Prisoners all look the same, but the Dynamite Expert is the one with the best education.

14481: Items and cargo can manipulate the ship speed.

14526: Oil can be pumped by a refinery, then later converted into electricity.
14527: Place your refinery around oil deposits. You can place oil wells on them from the refinery's menu.

14529: Oil can only be transported by railway. You need to connect your refinery to the oil harbor with rails.

14534: Power plants consume oil to produce electricity. They need to be connected by railway to your oil harbor.
14535: Electricity is given to buildings via the streets. Some production buildings require electricity to function; also your residents may ask for it. Other production buildings will see their productivity increase greatly with electricity.
14536: Your power plant needs to be connected by train to an oil harbor.
14537: Some buildings require electricity to function. Place a power plant near them, they will provide electricity via the streets.
14538: Define districts and bend the rules with the official buildings: equipped with items, they can impact your population and your production.
14540: He says that support for the Queen might be a benefit in your relationship.

14544: Mr. Ticker is impressed by your efforts and achievements, honoring your father.
14545: Thomas starts to see the good in you.
14546: Furnace and steelworks factories are quite slow. Working conditions can be adjusted per social class or per production chain, to increase the productivity.
14549: Request diplomatic treaties or cancel existing ones.
14550: Interact with this party to influence your reputation.
14552: The demolition expert Thomas N. Ticker questions the difference in working for you or Eli Bleakworth.
14554: Thomas N. Ticker disapproves of you trying to build a second Bright Sands.

She keeps it still, but her people's situation is desperate and demands her whole attention. She has agreed to yield the contract to you, on one condition: you must aid her refugees first.
14568: Isabel Sarmento asks you to secure her people before handing over Prosperity's contract.
14569: Fulfill Isabel Sarmento's demands to receive the Prosperity Sale contract
14570: Isabel Sarmento explains the danger on Prosperity and settling on other islands.
14571: Isabel believes you have better odds at hiding them from the Pyrphorians.
14577: Moves out to extinguish fires in the area of the fire station.
14578: Moves out to calm riots in the area of the police station.
14579: Moves out to cure illnesses in the area of the hospital.
14582: Without electricity, no one can visit or work in your monument.

14590: Sell Frigate [Conditions QuestCondition CurrentAmount]/[Conditions QuestCondition Amount] to Sir Archibald Blake
14592: Higher reputation raises the chance for better treaties.
14593: Many ships lost! Naval defeats follow with painful frequency, as calamitous maneuvers and decisions show weakness in leadership. Admiral first sealord asked for comment, but wiping tear from corner of his eye, he would only put his palm to his heart and solemnly sing the anthem.
14611: So many fine buildings lost to destruction! City ravaged by war! Architects frantically unroll emergency plans to rebuild as violence continues. Many parts of the city are unrecognisable! Full scale of devastation sketched out by ou artist-at-the-scene Henri Dugarry...
14612: Enemy makes mockery of our defences, seizing several key trading posts! Embarassing lack of prowess in war likely to spell the end, if wholesale changes to our forces are not undertaken soon! Revel in full scale of devastation as covered throughout today's edition.
14613: We have sunk countless ships— proof of titanic fortitude in the face of enemy aggression! As the waves swim red with the blood of our foe, whisky shoots from the nostrils of our admirals as they guffaw with laughter! More on the genius minds behind our navy below.
14614: Enemy structures crumble under fire! The crashes, bangs, and rumbles paralyse the enemy! Praise for our brave forces, and their ruthless expertise in demolition!
14615: The vast sea battle is unsurprisingly the major subject of discussion at home and abroad, with the outcome arguably decisive in settling the ongoing feud with our rivals. With the outcome in the balance, we must remain hopeful of a famous triumph. Continues p.3.
14616: Enemy fleet taken apart! Singular success for our proud fleet, in one of the largest sea battles in recent memory! Surely now the war shall be over, and all our enemies shall lay sword and shield at our feet in due deference! Speculation as to precisely how it was won pp.2-19.
14617: Humiliation! Huge sea battle ends as enemy cuts through our fleet! Eyewitness accounts of the failure sadly lost to the deep! Will crashing defeat finally condemn us to being forgotten footnote in history? Post-mortem continues pp. 2-15.
14618: Assault begins on our beloved home! Is it true we are left undefended by sea? That we must fight back this foe alone? Seeking advice as a civilian? We shall endeavour —for as long as we are able— to bring you round-the-dial reports on the situation.
14619: Rejoice, our city endures! Foolhardy enemy assault rebuffed after skirmishes! The coast is clear, at least for now. Debrief at headquarters due later today. Armchair accounts of the final battle in our beleaguered city correspondent's testimony throughout this edition.
14620: The enemy has captured [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], putting an end to our brave, but ultimately futile resistance. The local residents will have no choice but to swear allegaince with their new masters now.
14621: Enemy harbour receives barrage from our forces, sure to collapse under the indefatigable efforts of our nation, proudly united in the belief that this is a fine and wonderful idea. We here at this paper, certainly, are unanimous in our support!
14622: Assault on [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] ensures island is taken by force! The enemy resolve was whittled down, until their defences were breached, and a flagpole bearing our colours was driven deeply into the soil, to make official our newest territory!
14623: Overly optimistic assault on [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] duly ends in failure for our bumbling forces! Cavalier attitudes to the enemy will "not pay in the long run," say many worried this will now turn the tide against us!
14624: People of [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] already imagining life under enemy as their will to hold out wobbles. Reports show morale is at its lowest ebb! It cannot be long before we are forced to give up our city to the enemy for good!
14625: One of our rivals is besieged by an enemy fleet, news has filtered through from over the water. What is no doubt a disturbing development for them, may "not necessarily" be so grave for us, remarks our expert Commander Button, whose full appraisal may be enjoyed overleaf.
14626: The island of our rival will remain in their possession, following a successful defensive campaign against the enemy. Regardless of the result, the news is sure to be a relief to the long-suffering people on both sides.
14627: Our rival's island has fallen to the enemy, after a prolonged assault finally broke the local resistance. The transfer of ownership is immediate, but the lasting effects of this coup are yet to emerge as an outline from the clouds of gunpowder. More on Politics, pp3-5.
14629: [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] is a good samaritan, offering help to those in need. Recent success in trial of public responsibility proves our esteemed leader's equanimity in the face of adversity.
14631: Our sublimely philanthropic premier [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] achieves success after success in the public sphere, displaying remarkable compassion and willigness to intercede whenever others appear in need of support.
14633: [Participants Current Profile CompanyName] attempts to help, but only makes things worse! "It's all very well agreeing to do something, provided that you then do it," stated source close to our leader, wishing to remain nameless.
14635: [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] has become noticeably more attractive! Recent campaigns to beautifiy the city's avenues and boulevards have begun to pay dividends for tourism, as scenic vistas captivate the popular imagination.
14637: [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] "has let itself go," according to one of many visitors who claim the city is losing its appeal. Travel agents scratch their heads, saying, "there must be something we can do to get the turnstiles spinning again."
14638: MOST BEAUTIFUL CITY IN THE WORLD
14639: [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] is the fairest city of them all according to independent panel of aesthetes! In exhaustive list of magical destinations, our wondrous city emerged at the top! Scoff at the rest on the list pp. 24-25.
14641: [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] is now the most beautiful city ever built, most likely that shall "ever be built", according to renowned art historian. "A beauty timeless, universal— unsurpassable, may this singular jewel never be taken from us."
14643: A share in a rival company has been sold, we hear. The news broke during trading, and the full effects are not expected to be seen for a short while yet. It is not clear if the party who sold were forced into the sale, but the move won't fill their backers with confidence.
14645: Our company sells shares to a third-party! On the reasons for doing so, it is pure speculation. We debate the move in an opinion piece, questioning the long-term objectives, but in praise of the short-term gains of such an arrangement.
14647: We have sold our company shares in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], for reasons as yet unknown. "Perhaps the investment just wasn't paying off," says bookkeeper, "in which case it would be a sensible decision."
14649: Rival sells their share in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], for reasons as yet unknown. "Perhaps their investment just wasn't paying off," says bookkeeper, "in which case it is sensible for them to back down."
14651: Rival buys shares, targetting future takeover! Sinister intentions transparent at stakeholder meeting, according to sources present. A complete transfer of assets would be effectuated, should rival party ever hold a majority. Can we buy back a slice of the pie? pp. 13-14.
14653: A rival has bought shares in another business, according to reports. A prestige move for them, indubitably, but our economic expert writes of the inevitable repercussions in the small world of finance.
14655: Shares bought in rival business! A finger in the pie, leading to future takeover perhaps? While a sizeable initial outlay, the investment in our rivals can come good later. Should a majority ever be had, the door would open for a tantalising takeover.
14657: Shares bought back by rival! Company investment trumped by greater purchase power. The bi-monthly shareholder dinner was ruined by the news, with flabbergasted guests busting out of their suits.
14659: Shares now under our control again! A victory in the long struggle against a majority takeover, this decisive play could mean our independence is secured for sometime yet. Only with such determintaion can we show our would-be usurpers we mean business.
14660: HL - Hostile Takeover Share Bought Back NPC From NPC - Neutral
14661: SL - Hostile Takeover Share Bought Back NPC From NPC - Neutral
14663: Rival ready to seize [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName]! Catastrophic financial takeover seems inevitable! Not content with partial ownership, our adversary would seize this nest of ours, and all that lieth within, like the most indecent variety of cuckoo!
14665: An island is there for the taking, and opportunity never knocks twice at anyone's door! "More is more!" say hopeful henchpersons of our company, lips a-drool with the prospects such an acqusition would bring about.
14667: Devious hostile takeover success! Investment pays off, as new city joins the fold! A mail steamer brought with it amended company valuations for the start of trading— a great and instantaneous surge in assets! Improved portfolio is celebrated in our special pull-out within.
14669: [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] swiped by our rival! As hostile takeover goes through, does it spell the end for our company? What future plans for the place our rival has, are not ours to know, but grim faces on the streets tell the story.
14671: 3 rare and uncommon machines and inventions
14672: 3 rare and uncommon artifacts for your museum
14674: Lack of farmers in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] mean problems for local produce. "We need all the help we can get if the harvest is not to be a disaster," says one disgruntled local, left in the lurch.
14676: Lack of able workers causing problems for industry in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName]. "I told the guv, I don't have the experience to work in this section alone," said one chagrined employee, wishing to remain anonymous.
14678: Too few Artisans in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] means local craft will suffer. "When I said I enjoyed the isolation, I didn't imagine being forever alone..." weeps beleaguered local dandy, hand upon brow.
14680: Not enough Engineers in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] to keep city in good working order, says survey. "It's terrible, the lack of investment in further research," pencil-chewing curiosity remarks. More bad science, pp. 19-20.
14682: A lack of investment in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName] is extremely damaging for the local economy, financial report shows. "It's a damned farce," was the only comment we could extract from those who had already given their backing in the region.
14684: Jornaleros workforce dwindles in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName], with even the old guard admitting they need some fresh blood. "Alpaca will not do all this work, she'll give up, run back to the foothills," fears overburdened local.
14686: Obreros are too few in number to keep their visioon of the future alive in [Newspaper FindArticle([RefGuid]) Context TownName]. "This place, is too much in the past. When will we grow and move on?" says earnest and principled resident.
14689: Safety inspections in [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName] show that town industry is unlikely to experience too many blow-outs. "The possibility always remains," inspector remarks, "while the accompanying science is still in its infancy."
14691: Haphazard management of industry in [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName] means a catastrophic blow-out is "likely", according to quivering investigator, "we are dabbling in that we don't understand!"
14693: Roof blows off industrial heart of [Newspaper SelectedNewspaper Article([RefGuid]) Context TownName]! Tremendous boom precedes widespread destruction by fire, as something goes terribly, terribly wrong in one of its factories, with lack of council foresight blamed.
