800776:
Not sturdy enough! A hard knock on the rapids leaves your men clutching timber. It is only then they realise they are being watched. There is laughter from the riverbank, before the bystanders pull them from the water at gunpoint.
'One false move and we kill you,' growls their leader. It appears these are Isabel's people. If only you could prove you share in their cause.
800877: These parasites must have come from the marsh goo; all that waist-high wading. Now they nestle deep in your crew, who, at risk of harm from their own madcap cures, really need professional help!
800881: A delectable disinfectant! The suffering take immense pleasure scouring themselves in a whacking great tub of the stuff. Indeed, so diverting is this new form of alcohol absorption, that even those without parasites take turns.
800882: The doctor concocts a panacea, which not only purges the belly-dwelling roundworm, but more besides. Garlic, wormwood, and lemon quietly see off a myriad other complaints of your spoon-dodging sailors.
800883: The doctors disagree. 'Madam! Bloodletting gives our patients only a fifty-fifty chance!' says one. 'Sir, tinctures are seldom beneficial OR effective on parasites!' says the other.
800884: It does go away, eventually. 'My arm looked like a wormcake for a while,' one sailor laments, 'but that little smattering of holes filled-up with pus now - signs my body is winning the war.'
800885: Mass amputation for all?! The festering parasites have gnawed their way to bone! Limbs must be chopped, or else their bodies shall rattle with bemaggoted cavities!
800889: A fine placebo. As if by magic, the intestinal worms lose the will to go on. The doctor freely admits this is more likely down to positive patient attitude, than his revolting tincture.
800890: The unpleasant medicine doesn't help. Constant trips to the privy are now the only release for your bug-ridden crew. The doctor admits to the failure of the tincture, but thankfully has something for diarrhoea.
800891: The tincture is poison! Having seen their first shipmate choke on his dose, the rest decide they'd rather live with a six-foot tapeworm in their bellies.
800892: Somehow it works, and the patients are rid of the parasite. The doctor seems unsurprised, 'human physiology may be complex, but treatment need not be.' A pretty vague case summary, but who cares?!
800893: Perfect preparation for amputation! At least that's what your crazed doctor would have you believe... Once her macabre experiment is concluded there is surely only one course of action for the afflicted...
800894: It does go away, eventually. 'My arm looked like a wormcake for a while,' one sailor laments, 'but that little smattering of holes filled-up with pus now - signs my body is winning the war.'
800895: Mass amputation for all?! The festering parasites have gnawed their way to bone! Limbs must be chopped, or else their bodies shall rattle with bemaggoted cavities!
800901: As good as could be expected. Out with parasites, in with polished peg legs and helpful hook-hands. The crew look not nearly as enthusiastic as you might think however.
800902: Extraordinary that you trusted that quack! She is sideshow surgeon, carving up her victims with the zeal of a ripper, and the accuracy of a pissing schoolboy. At least the screams will die away soon enough...
800903: Nothing can save them. Though a mercy that they may choose their manner of death - unmolested by the ship's quack - it is death nonetheless. The parasite has sucked the life from your expedition.
800933: Trapped in the snow! When the furious blizzard relents, the exploration party see the mountain pass ahead is blocked. Some say the rough terrain can be crossed, others say they saw a small fork in the path not too far back.
800935: Craft something to traverse the terrain
800938: The crew feel happy awe, at the resulting avalanche. There, as the pass beyond is revealed, they swear they see something lurching away. Giant and hirsute, it leaves no print but in the imagination.
800939: The skis are highly effective. Simply fashioned, and with a clever coating of paraffin. Some prove expert skiers, glissading with a flourish to the finish line, but all make it to the bottom. The whole thing has turned out to be a good bit of fun.
800943: It is not much of a detour. The going is steady and before long the warm fire of the base camp appears in view. The blizzard is something to tell the grandchildren, provided frostbite hasn't seen to that...
800944: The path is both steep and perilous. A narrow ledge along a sheer cliff lies ahead. Some men are ready to give up. All the while a strange noise keens below the gnashing gale.
800945: A far more treacherous path, but your crew are committed now. A steep cliff ahead must be negotiated, and your ropes are too short.
800946: Shelter is minimal. Huddling cannot keep out the cold. When a rescue party arrives with equipment the next morning, they find men frostbitten and hypothermic. Not all of them will survive the journey down.
800947: Toboggans are better where it's flat. Though solidly made, the going is fast. One sled veers into a ravine. A cry below: 'Officer injured', but the wind is picking up.
800948: The clumsy snowshoes fail you. Whether it is in their design or construction, every step sinks the party deeper. They do not yet know, but the cold will take them all.
800952: The doctor works quickly. Just what is needed with another blizzard brewing. 'Temporary strapping,' he says, 'but should get us home.' The officer and rest of the party make shelter with little time left to spare.
800953: The doctor knows nothing of urgency. 'Give my patient space!' he snaps at those trying to move things along. Meanwhile, a blizzard sweeps the ravine, and the onset of frostbite is enough to split the party. Neither the doctor nor his unfortunate patient are to be seen again.
800954: You knew deep down not all would make it. 'They're all returned but the injured fellow,' comes the news. 'There was no saving him, the way he was. Ice stripped the meat from his bones like a chef's mandorre.'
800956: Urge your party to face their fears
800957: A heavenly, enlightened voice calls. None stop to look down, so enchanted are they. Over a verge, appears a shrine with a great bell - the source of the sound - and beyond, a pilgrims' path to the foot of the mountain.
800958: A non-believer falls to his death. 'Those lacking conviction shall be tried and judged in this place,' echoes the priest. The rest edge to safety, consoled by the apparent goodness in their hearts.
800960: Nothing but a demonic howl. The blizzard rises anew. Without hope to keep them aloft, it is no surprise when a ledge gives way, damning to hell below.
800961: A song of solidarity rises through the line of snow-crusted faces. Clinging to what they most cherish, they edge to safety. Had they not been reminded of such incentives, it is doubtful they would have survived.
800962: Only some take strength. The rest remain in a frozen huddle. They may have lacked courage to negotiate the high ledge, but will welcome in their icy death with creditable stoicism.
800965: Craft longer ropes and swing down
800966: All are saved, at a cost. Putting the ropes together is quite a task with frozen fingers. That the party are able to cling to the rope as they descend is a small miracle. Nevertheless, frostbite will do lasting damage to their digits.
800967: A small but critical detail is overlooked. Grip. A man falls from the top of the rope with a cry, tumbling those below him into the abyss like meat from a skewer. Only a few frozen grimaces survive.
800968: It is a risky business. Though the cliff isn't lacking in handholds, this is a test of individual endurance. Some were never going to be up to it. As they fall, the will to survive in the others strengthens.
800973: Everything points towards the foreboding gate. Salvation lies beyond, but the eerie blue flame that suffuses it keep the crew at a distance. Perhaps it would be safer to find a way through the surrounding jungle, but those of faith say the gate is 'an auspicious sign'.
800974: Have the scientist look at the gate
800975: Have faith and leap through the flames.
800976: Wrap up before leaping through the flames.
800978: The scientist banishes the illusion. 'This fire that you perceive around the gate, is simply the agglomeration of azure glow-worms.' Laughter becomes delight, as the party take the pulsing creatures in hand. This is the wonder of nature.
800979: If anything the flames are cool, almost like bundles of ribbons brushing the skin. This gate is, without question, an earthly manifestation of the divine. Ahead, an extremely hospitable settlement affirms the holy blessing.
800980: The doubtful crew are surprised. Drawing closer to the gate, they find the flames seem to give off no heat. One leap of faith and they are through! Still they hesitate, for a perfect skeleton sits propped against it.
800981: Fire and brimstone! The heat is intense, but your procession of false prophets seem numb to the pain. The others watch horrified, as fabric, skin and flesh renders before their eyes. If the expedition continues, it will only be for the mercy of god.
800984: The doctor forms a reasonable hypothesis, but cannot be absolutely sure from bone alone. 'The way they sit suggests they lacked the will to continue.' Not wishing to end the same way, the crew are astonished to discover that leaping through the gate does them no harm.
800985: The doctor's career is over. As are the careers of those who heed his words. 'Came through from the other side, but it was not the fire that took him'. As they jump, flames grasp their ankles, and rapidly shoot up and over the rest.
800986: 'Ouch!' The men yelp, rolling in the dirt until they are sure they are no longer afire. The strange arch behind them, your brave soldiers compare their battle scars.
800987: 'Cowards!' Your men lack the military discipline to follow a simple order! You will have to find another way.
800988: They make it. Rolled-up like carpets they skip through the flaming gate. Their worst complaint is the sweet and overwhelming pong of sweat that now follows them.
800989: 'That they died as sausages! or what shall we tell their families!?' Perhaps dousing their mantles in a protective layer of paraffin was a mistake! Your expedition continues to turn on its spit.
800990: The crew have no regrets in plotting such a rational course. Sweaty jungles are the devil they know, crawling with tentacle limb and spider fang. But who knew what sorcery governed that strange gate?
800991: The jungle thins out to a precipice. A long and shoddy-looking bridge stretches to the other side, or else you could attempt to find a way around.
800992: No way through, thanks to your shambolic mapreading. The group becomes separated, and eventually lost. Hacking those ancient and contorted roots has saved no time that couldn't be saved by backtrack, and cost you several lives into the bargain.
800995: It is in passable condition. There are a few nerve-wracking moments, as the wind whips the bridge into a vigorous sway, and all are rather pleased to reach the other side. Your expedition continues.
800996: Most treacherous! The confidence of your craftsmen in the rickety structure couldn't be more misplaced. Of course it is nothing if not dramatic, when the bridge cables twang, and one after the other pile into the gorge.
800997: It is a long trek, that could have been much longer but for the competence of those with a compass. Yet another hiccup for the expedition log book.
800998: Imbecile orienteers! There is no other way across this river valley for a hundred miles! You have covered half that distance before you realise, wasting a lot of time and provisions.
801002: The discovery of several strange artefacts aboard spooks the crew. Tied to the rigging, bunks, boards, and even atop the captain's desk. A warning, a threat? And who put them there? Since the nearby island is uninhabited, it is sensible only to think the perpetrator must be aboard. The crew must know or have seen something last night!
801004: Ask the crew who did this
801005: Throw them overboard and move on.
801006: 'For good luck,' remarks the anthropologist, inspecting the spherical red dolls, 'for the setting of goals, and perseverance in achieving them. Some people or spirit of this place believe they can help us home.' At this, your crew are beguiled.
801007: Your crew are beginning to bond. Someone comes forward, not having expected to cause such a bother. 'They're for me old mum,' he sighs, 'birds - that one's a little robin. Made 'em together when she was ill. Now she's gone...I...' The others are quick to put an arm round his shoulder; they're all in this together.
801008: No one has anything to offer but the priest. It is his belief that some unholy chapter has opened. The next morning, more of the eerie things have appeared. 'Cleanse the idols in holy fire!' he shrieks. 'Nonsense,' says a soldier. "Set guards within, and we shall have this rat."
801009: A destructive episode. No one has information, or perhaps they withhold it. Consensus tends towards the latter. Someone wants this expedition to fail, and these effigies are a threat. Paranoia festers. At the next port, a large part of the crew opts to quit.
801010: Chilling. As instructed, the crew collect the dolls and throw them overboard. But relief lasts only until the following morning, when the dolls are found returned, placed exactly as they had been.
801011: Side with the priest and prepare a holy fire
801012: Keep guard and capture the perpetrator
801013: The priest gloats over his success. With a maniacal grin, he sets the mound of idols alight. The fire consumes rapidly, shifting vermillion to viridian. Some say they hear the wood scream as it goes. 'Expurgation is God's work, and I am chosen.'
801014: The fire is chaotic, and the buckets of water seem not to extinguish, but provoke. The flame leaps to the priest's cassock like spring-heeled jack, and as it sweeps up his back, he is heard to utter his last words, 'forgive me father, for I have sinned.'
801015: The teenagers are remorseful. 'It was a jape, a piece o' trickery sirs, we regret t'were not received so.' The crew are forgiving - the youths merely wished to contain their homesickness - and call for just fifty strokes of the birch per bottom.
801016: That night, dire musket-shot is heard. A dead boy on deck, local. A second is seen diving to blue. Next morning a rhythm comes from an armada of river boats, armed with guns. There island is inhabited, and they know what you have done.
801017: The sun is solemn that morning. The bodies of the dead guards are borne to the hold for burial, but not here, upon this cursed rock. Who killed them none know but the sinister effigies. The expedition fumbles on.
801020: One warning salvo is enough. The river boats cluster and slow. Though they lower their weapons and allow you to leave, the anger that your crime goes unpunished couldn't be more marked in their faces.
801021: Your ship is a sitting duck. Your crew cannot man stations fast enough to fire or manoeuvre. Enemy boats surround your ship, before scaling its sides. The blood shed on both sides will stain this ship and expedition forever.
801022: Once your ship is underway she is free. Nevertheless your adversaries are excellent shots, and do damage to the sails and aft. The crew will have to make repairs in the days that follow.
801023: A traumatic escape. In the hurry to leave, your ship is spun broadside and exposed to gunfire. There are injuries, but none so deep as the sight of the dead boy's accomplice below. He weeps, and clutches one of the idols - a good luck charm.
801026: Robbed! Thanking the generous innkeeper, your ship is ready to leave. Everyone at the dock smiles and waves you off, and no wonder, valuable equipment is later discovered to be missing. You must decide now if it's worth going back for.
801029: Return disguised and bait the robbers
801030: Ask the local authorities to take action
801031: Take the loss on the chin
801032: The detective already knows. 'I was waiting to see if our crew were complicit, but am satisfied they are not.' Your ship returns and lays a watertight case before the local authorities. With the guilty arrested your equipment is returned and your ship fully resupplied gratis.
801033: Swift justice. Petty defences crumble in the dawn light. Your ship yawns unopposed into the smouldering harbour, and turns its guns upon the harbourmaster's office. 'Please, take anything!' he yelps.
801034: Your assault is too slow. As you gain the upper hand over the harbour defences, the cavalry appear. Cannons pop from the west; local authorities come as reinforcement.
801035: An absolute shambles. Couldn't even best a few locals and their primitive demi-cannon. 'What shall defeat us next?' yelp those who are not killed by the blast, 'A small, but angry gang of tortoises?'
801037: You put an end to corruption! Brought to their knees, the local authorities admit a conspiracy in which all are involved. 'It was never meant to go this far. We vow our people shall never rob again!' Proud to have effected change, you take back your possessions and leave.
801038: The enemy force is vast. 'How many are there, captain!? We must turn back.' But it is too late. Soon it is not just the western cliff lit up with cannonfire, but your ship. Many lives will be lost before you crawl out of range.
801039: Make peace, and reason with the officials.
801040: They are wiling to listen. After an exasperating few days, you are finally able to prove your losses. The authorities take in the guilty dockers, and most, but not all of your possessions are returned.
801041: The authorities stand with their own. You put your case as best you can, but it's not enough. Furthermore, you must answer for the damage you've caused. Unfortunately, this means leaving one of your best behind to help with repairs.
801042: You rumble the schemers! The crew set aside superstition, daubing your ship a new name. Cut-throat sailors pose as officers, with cabin curtains repurposed as sashes to mark them strangely. Taken in by it all, the innkeeper and his dockside associates are caught in the act. You make sure to relieve them of far more than they stole.
801043: It works, at first. A lick of paint, and the ship differs enough to blend in at the busy port. Moustaches and clothes aren't enough for the crafty innkeeper though. 'Thought you could fool us?' he scoffs.
801044: With feeble disguises, your party can't believe the inn doesn't out them. But then there's laughter, as patrons turn in unison, guns held to your heads. 'Better hope its not cold where you go!' the innkeeper says. Your crew are stripped, bound, and packed off to sea.
801045: Take back what is yours by force
801047: Sometimes a fistfight is the only way. The inn is a hurricane of chair and glass, as your crew express themselves the only way they know how. Once the locals are subdued, the innkeeper is dragged outside, his life now security against whatever plunder you please.
801048: The locals are brutal. Home-made knuckles, knives and cudgels scrape open the faces of your crew. Some are to bleed out on the sticky hostelry floor, the bloody remainder, to be packed off by the authorities for disturbance of the peace.
801049: The innkeeper relents. 'We've got a good thing going here, and I don't want you spoiling it,' he sniffs, 'take what's yours and leave.' The crew have back what they lost, but thoughts are spared for the scheme's next unwary victims.
801050: 'Get out, before we scratch you out!' growls the innkeeper, true colours plain. It seems the whole port is on his side. The expedition must take the loss of time and equipment on the chin.
801051: You make the case well. 'You are quite right. Terrible corruption such as this must be put to an end!' says the governor, 'you shall have back what was taken.' His disingenuousness stinks to high heaven, but there's no time for deeper digging.
801052: They are corrupt. 'What a fantastical story. I am so glad our country has fired your imagination!' smiles the governor.
801055: 'Clever. Very clever.' He lights a cigar. 'How did you know the innkeeper was my brother?' Your emissary sensibly avoids the truth that it was guesswork. 'Take whatever you want,' he says gesturing to a warehouse bursting with seized goods.
801056: 'That was your last mistake,' chuckles the governor, as his poplar-lined palace swarms with militia, 'arrest these fops!' Your delegation try to resist, but they are armed only with the toothpicks that came with their canapes. Your expedition must manage without them.
801057: 'Alright, alright!' says the amused governor, bayonet to his neck, 'take what you want. But then you leave.' Since the harbour is now well-guarded, you've done well to force a compromise.
801058: 'That was a mistake,' chuckles the governor, as his poplar-lined palace swarms with militia, 'arrest them!' Your crew would rather die than be locked-up for life, so they fight their way out. At least, one or two of them do.
801060: Widespread frustration among the crew. 'The instruments were vital for my research!', 'You let those beggars off scot free?!', 'This expedition is an embarrassment!' Hard to argue with their assessment, and bad for morale.
801061: Widespread frustration among the crew. 'The instruments were vital for my research!', 'You let those beggars off scot free?!', 'This expedition is an embarrassment!' Hard to argue with their assessment, and bad for morale.
801064: Water has dribbled almost to nothing during an inland survey, en route to the rendezvous. But hope springs eternal! A muddy river strikes through the arid basin. The crew are delirious when they realise it is not completely dried-up. Do you stop for water, or press on?
801066: Fashion a device to extract water from mud.
801067: Look for the source of the river
801069: The botanist foams at the mouth with thirst-quenching theories. 'The best idea may be these trees. Cut them just here, and catch the drip of water beneath,' they say, as they take a knife to the bark. Before an hour has passed, there's enough water to soothe a beached humpback.
801070: 'The secret is boiling the water', says one resourceful survivalist, 'and needless to say a mixture of charcoal, sand and cloth makes a fine filter.' With water drawn, filtered and boiled, the crew can be sure it is safe to drink. Time even for a mud bath - your safari brigade slopping about like happy hippo.
801071: The water still has a mighty pong, despite all solids having been separated out by the rudimentary device. Several feel terribly ill after drinking. A treatment can be improvised, or the survey can try to hold out until the rendezvous.
801072: Hours under hot sun, for fatally little. Countless designs in the soil, and no prototype. When something is finally cobbled together, the fools test their stupid sieve with the last of the clean supply. It will be a miracle now if anyone survives.
801073: Finding a river source is easy, but turning it into a shortcut...? That takes brains. High above the dry basin, water piles blissfully into the gully. The men wouldn't miss a swim beneath a waterfall for the world!
801074: There's water, if you can get to it. Hippos are gathered all along the bank. This is their territory. If you don't refill here, there's no guarantee you'll find water further on.
801075: Following a river should have been easy. But your party are so focused on distant goals, they fail to look immediately ahead. Suddenly, a man shoots downward as if yanked by giant hands. There are holes everywhere - an underground system of caves, and a tomb for your unlucky crew.
801076: There was never enough water for all of them. A freak mist has the crew licking air with cracked tongues, but nothing can keep the wolf from the door. Several drop dead as old bone, before the safari staggers to the rendezvous camp.
801079: The sickness clears over time. 'With dysentery the patient must rest,' the sensible doctor said, 'away from the others.' With the last of the good water, and gentle nursing, the caravan reaches the rendezvous in fair health.
801080: No-one is ready for dysentery. The sick are empty and weak, no fluids to replenish all they have lost. With only vague measures in place to prevent the spread, savannah delirium reigns. The survey never reaches the rendezvous.
801081: Haste saves some, but not all. Dysentery is thoroughly set in by the time the survey makes the rendezvous. Although the camp provides the sick every comfort, for many the rigours of the sickness prove too much.
801085: Wait for nightfall, hoping they leave
801086: Back off and try something else
801087: Hip hip hooray! The hippos run as fast as their stout legs will carry them. The serenity of the river bank is utterly destroyed, but none of your crew care, as they help themselves to bucketfuls of clean and highly quaffable drinking water.
801088: Someone knows their hippopotami. A kinship with the animals allows the gentle river bank to be shared. Fresh water is relayed by the bucket. A few nervous moments as a large female rears out of the water, but she just wants a bird to pick her teeth. Satisfied, the crew resume their trek to the rendezvous.
801089: There's movement in the hippo camp, as the crew approach, followed by violent evacuations of their gigantic nostrils. Mandolin jaws open wide in display, and it is pretty clear to the crew they have no choice but to back off.
801090: A game of unhappy hippos ensues! The water swirls with their pudgy bodies. They snort and scream, and prepare to charge.
801092: Immediately run away and leave the area entirely
801093: Cold, but effective. The brigade focus fire at the closest hippo, and soon it is dead. The other hippos falter, bellowed howls of grief echoing around the basin. As the blood of the majestic animal suffuses with the river, your crew must now find the audacity to drink.
801094: The hippos bowl into your nine-pin soldiers. One is dead on impact. Others die slow, trampled or drowning, matchstick guns floating downriver like poohsticks. There's almost no-one left to make the rendezvous.
801095: Escape is more panic than anything else, but the crew are spooked. Lurching through the water with hippos at their backs is not something they are lining up to try again.
801096: Aquatic combat is a key discipline. What small guilt the crew feel about driving the poor hippos from their patch is overcome by a will to survive. Out here, it is such ruthlessness that separates the living from the dead.
801097: What shot hits, barely passes through blubber. The whole bloat of hippos charge, leaving them an instant to make a decision.
801100: Cold, but effective. The brigade focus fire at the closest hippo, and soon it is dead. The other hippo falter, bellowed howls of grief echoing around the basin. As the blood of the majestic animal suffuses with the river, your crew must now find the audacity to drink.
801101: The hippos bowl into your nine-pin soldiers. One is dead on impact. Others die slow, trampled or drowning, matchstick guns floating downriver like poohsticks. There's almost no-one left to make the rendezvous.
801102: Escape is more panic than anything else, but the crew are spooked. Lurching through the water with hippos at their backs is not something they are lining up to try again.
801103: Hardly seems worth waiting for. The hippos wallow all evening, leaving only as night falls to graze. The crew have lost half a day's march on the rendezvous, for a bit of muddy water.
801104: A waste of time. The hippos leave at dusk to graze. Unfortunately, their patch is just a stone's throw away. Their aqueous eyes can be seen glistening in the moonlight, and no-one wants to risk it.
801580: You have found a radiant relic! The crew toast the success of your archaeological expedition. May we now better understand what it is to be human!
801588: Unusual debris float among the waves. Mold-ridden planks of wood, strings of cloth, fragments of broken plaster, all tinted by the gray shade of time. Filled with childish excitation, the crew discusses the possibility of going underwater to uncover the debris' origin.
801589: Send your diver into the depths
801592: The diver plunges into the ocean with fish-like ease. He follows the trail of debris through the murky waters and almost smacks into a wall of indescribable height. Unsure whether the obstacle is natural or man-made, the diver wanders along its smooth facade until he finds an uncanny artefact and resurfaces with it. His account of the underwater mystery fascinates the crew.
801593: The diving bell looks decent and feels solid. Two men climb aboard and the bell plunges into the depths while a whole group of sailors pumps air into its ventilation tube. The bell descends until it is stopped by a surface of coral. Underneath the colorful shapes, the sailors notice a silver coin on their left and a gaping, perfectly circular hole on their right.
801594: The homemade diving bell falls apart. The engineers, specialized in complex ship machinery, have no idea on how to make such a simple device. Their machine departs with two men onboard, and they continue to dive while the bell itself stays afloat. When the divers emerge, the engineers take an earful and the crew is too disheartened to make a new attempt.
801595: Hope that it will resist the dive and push the bell into the hole
801596: Pick up the coin and resurface
801597: Their trust in the work of their comrades pays. The bell slithers in a slow fall which allows the bewitched divers to take in the view. This is no sunken ship: the engraved hole was a window among a hundred more lining a hall of ridiculous proportions. A single ray of light, pouring from the hole, accompanies the bell's descent until it lands on what might have been statue alcoves. A shining green pearl lies in the lowest part of the alcove.
801598: The bell doesn't resist the fall. Instead of gliding along the sides of the hole, the bell tilts, letting the water in. The men call for help and the crew immediately tries to pull them up, fighting against what rocks snare the bell, doing their best to save their mates, and unable to react when the rope snaps into their hands. They are left to mourn their sea-buried companions.
801599: Ignore the pearl and risk the dive into darkness
801600: Retrieve the pearl from the dead-end and resurface
801601: Call it luck or miracle, but the bell holds. One of the men lights the bell's lamp and the other dives, following the glow as it illuminates the silent scene below: ghostly statues of hunting scenes, collapsed frescoes depicting plentiful gardens, and a massive throne of fractured marble on which a sword waits, covered in fluttering kelp. When the artifact is brought back to the surface and cleaned up, it reveals a weapon of exquisite quality, embedded with unknown jewels and metals.
801602: Lady Luck does not smile for the faithless. As the bell descends into the dark, so does the pressure rise and press against the makeshift protection. The sailors pull the signal rope in a panic, but despite their fervent prayers, they are not pulled up in time. All that the crew manages to retrieve from the sea are the broken bell and its broken contents.
801604: Low risk, low reward. The diving bell emerges without a scratch and the crew enjoys the tiny silver coin, passing it around and commenting on its singular aspect. Their excitement can only survive for so long and the coin is stored in the officers' coffers while the sailors whisper what ifs leading to grander treasures.
801605: The sailors protest but understand the risk. As the ship goes on its way, its wake drowns the singular ruins and their promise of adventure.
801609: The crew faces the bloody customs of foreign lands. After a night of feasting, the sailors believe that meeting the foreign prince and his sea-traveling court is the highlight of their trip. However, morning comes with news of a sudden death among the court, and your crew is immediately accused of murder. The prince demands a trial by combat and your men are left with little freedom but the choice of the challenge's nature.
801610: Send your strongest fighter for a brawl
801611: Send your best shot for a pistol duel
801612: Send your brightest officer for a trial of wits
801613: What could a lord do against a sea-forged champion? The prince's warrior is nothing more than a scarecrow in shiny armor, and your own cotton-clad fighter scoffs at his tacky opponent. The walking wardrobe is tripped, grabbed, and thrown overboard in a single movement. As per foreign laws, your crew receives compensation and their name is cleared.
801614: No word is brutal enough to describe your opponent. If his plate armor is scaled to match the man inside, then that man is a giant. The human mountain reaches to grab your fighter and crushes his skull like he would an apple. Word of your crew's feebleness and alleged crimes is sent for all cities to know and spread.
801615: Your gunslinger shoots faster than his own shadow. His opponent drops to the ground before anyone can see or even understand that a gun has been fired, and only the banging sound and fuming barrel testify to the attack. The prince wonders how lucky your sharpshooter is, then reluctantly graces the crew and presents them with compensation for his offence.
801616: Speed is not in your gunslinger's vocabulary. The prince's duelist, displaying the look of men who fill graves but never dig them, is the sharpest shooter your sailors have ever seen. Your best shot is dead before he even touches the handle of his gun. Judging his passing to be too low a price, the prince randomly selects men among your crew and has them hanged for good measure.
801617: The foreigners are drawn in by your officer's pace. He inspects the body, noticing knife cuts of varying depths and bleeding. Through methodical questioning, the officer presses the foreigners and reveals the deception: each wound was made by a different hand, the victim was killed by all of them! The prince buys the sailors' silence and they leave wondering what could have motivated the curious murder.
801618: A mute would have pleaded better. The officer engages in a battle of arguments with the prince's vizier, and each of his meager claims are met with factual evidence of their contrary. The prince cuts the exchange with exasperation and has the officer taken to be quartered till torn apart as a final judgement for the supposed crime. No scream ever matches the ones heard that day.
801621: The ship has hit an iceberg! Navigating in the dark proved to be folly: what little lighting the ship provides for itself does not compensate for the absence of moonlight. A low thud shakes the entire boat, and the swinging lights of night lanterns reveal the rampart-like block of ice they have run into. A crevice splits the iceberg and the ship is stuck inside.
801623: Bombard the ice with all cannons
801624: Build a device to push the ice away
801626: No obstacle can prevail before human might. Sticks of dynamite are tied to the iceberg's flanks and lit in a perfect synchrony, exploding in a tidy and devastatingly efficient manner. Impressed by their own skill, the crew happily resumes the trip.
801627: The iceberg crumbles under the impressive firepower of the ship. The port and starboard cannons are fired, denting the ice inch by inch until it breaks into pieces which fall into the water with huge splashes. The ship's iron prow pushes against the formidable obstacle and breaks through under the cheers of the crew.
801628: Those puny cannons cannot take down the wall of ice. Frozen shards rain on the deck with each new cannon blast, and they cut and slice into the sailors - tiny wounds which make it seem like the iceberg is fighting back. The crevice surrounding the ship has gotten bigger, but still refuses to let it go.
801629: Climb the iceberg to plant explosives inside
801630: The iceberg is weakened, wait for it to melt
801631: A risky reward for a risky attempt. Using what nails and planks they can hammer into the wall of ice, a group of sailors climbs it and manages to reach its top, where they plant a barrel of gunpowder. The explosion lights the night, pulverizes the wall, and nicks the ship's hull. The vessel can leave after light repairs.
801632: Climbing does not simply consist of walking upwards. The men slip, slide, shift and totter, and their best effort resides in climbing on each other's shoulders to try and reach new heights. They don't, and the human ladder crashes onto the deck, leaving all of its rungs bent or definitively broken. The remaining crew must wait for the ice to melt by itself before they can leave.
801633: Days melt into weeks which melt into months. With each passing moment, the ice grows a bit weaker, but constant observation makes it seem like nothing is changing. The wait drives the crew restless and their tension escalates into regular, if unjustified, brawls. When the ice finally lets them go, all sailors have gained their small share of madness.
801634: The crew assembles a perfect lever to free the ship. Unbolting the decorative guardrail of the prow and roping it to the starboard railing, they manage to create a semblance of a pry bar which sneaks between the hull and the ice and pushes the latter away. The sailors row their way out to the cadence of a beloved song.
801635: There is a difference between imagining and actually creating. The lever mechanism devised by the engineers is as unmanageable as it is ugly and the shape of the thing, which defies the very concept of aesthetics, is a testimony to its chaotic behaviour. The crew gives up any idea of building their own escape device.
801636: Patience and good faith reward the sailors' prayers. The following day is devoid of clouds or wind and the perfect weather attracts fishing boats to deeper seas. The stuck ship is seen and rescued right away. The navigators hasten to warn their fellow seamen of the danger and are even offered a space in the prestigious Practical Pilot navigation guide. Such an accident will never happen again!
801637: Prayers take a long time to reach whoever is listening. The crew waits, digging into their supplies and entertaining themselves however they can. Rescue finally comes after one full week in the form of a whaler which drags the ship out from its ice prison, and the sailors, relieved but tired, can't help but wonder if they could have made it out on their own.
801638: Nobody is answering these prayers. After days of idling in the cold and gnawing through their supplies and patience, the crew's discontent rises to the extent that they cannot bear to wait any longer. If help does come, it will come from themselves.
801643: Your crew attempts the crossing of a vicious strait. Like Odysseus along the coasts of Sicily, they see a subsidiary current running counter to the main flow, its strength so wild it brings fish with deformed eyes and luminescent bellies to the surface. What creatures are not swallowed by this whirlpool end up impaled on the shore's nasty teeth.
801646: Avoid the whirlpool and maneuver to dodge the shore
801647: Avoid the shore and hope the whirlpool won't suck the ship in
801648: Odysseus didn't have the ability of your navigators. Through a series of tight maneuvers and expert understanding of the furious currents, they drive the ship between the whirlpool and the shore, using the provided momentum to dash ahead. The moment is a brief as it is intense and the crew rejoices, laughing like children under the cold droplets of crashing waves.
801649: The maneuver is even more complicated than expected. The ship is driven alongside the whirlpool and flirts with the shore, the racket of the water covering the orders shouted by officers. The current speeds up, inexorably pulling the ship towards the reef.
801650: Fear clouds the navigators' readings. Unable to choose between several possible courses which could all end in disaster, they opt for a stunned silence and let the crew maneuver on their own. The ship crashes on the shore in an explosion of metal and wood which sends a dozen men overboard and straight into the rock fangs of the coast. It is more a wreck than a ship which escapes the deadly strait.
801651: Spin the ship to take the damage on its flank
801652: Bombard the shore in an attempt to slow the ship
801653: A frontal crash is avoided, but it is a crash nonetheless. The whole ship protests against the unnatural movement, its rudder straining against the current and its hull complaining loudly against the maneuver until the impact silences it. The repairs are much lighter than they could have been.
801654: Your navigators cannot control the wild ship. The maneuver sends it spinning and it plunges into the reef prow first. If it weren't for the metal cast protecting the vessel, the crew would have been crushed as well. The repairs, which take place both in the swirling waters and on the knife-like rocks, are excruciating.
801655: Power faces power in a risky but successful attempt. All cannons are fired in the shore's direction, in a surprisingly efficient effort to slow the ship down. The ship lands on the devastated coast and the hull is barely grated by the remains of the broken stone spears.
801656: What did they expect, attacking nature itself? The massive teeth of stone barely tremble under the cannon's fire, and the recoil is a futile strength against the voracious current. The rock jaw catches the ship and grinds the upper deck, sending several sailors to be served as the strait's daily food.
801657: The sailors' fright gives them wings. The crew reacts to each order with unparalleled speed, too occupied to plead the heavens to think of discussing the risky manoeuvres that are asked of them. When at last the whirlpool is passed, their belief that the Almighty might have his eyes on this ship is stronger than ever.
801658: There are only so many disasters faith can prevent. When they understand that the whirlpool is a monster none should face, the sailors fall to their knees to pray and beg, abandoning what meaningless impact they could have had on the ship's trajectory. Like Circe prophesied to Odysseus, the currents attack the ship, the men, and a hero.
801665: Through the canons heavy smoke, the lookout sees a Pyrphorian gunboat sailing away and disappearing in the distance. The contract might be on board, chasing the ship is crucial! While the crew sails away in the same direction, it is time to think about a strategy.
801666: Study the maps to estimate its next supply stop and the way to it

801904:
Discouraged, the crew comes back to Izabel's island. "We lost them" says the captain. But a few days afterward, Izabel receives a letter: "Pyrphorian spotted in Montoya harbour. Their ship is docked but their hide is nowhere to be found." Receiving this information, the crew leaves at once.
Montoya harbour is huge, clearly a centre for commerce in the region. But it is also known to be a gathering point for all the scum and criminals who have their networks here. Finding people here will be tricky.
801905: Convince the harbour master to give information about the Pyro ship occupants
801906: Diplomat manage to make the crew appears as authority figures, ready to take care of the problems the ship owners cause in the city. The harbour master is relieved ship to repair the wrong they have been doing. "Every time they come here iit is a nightmare for us! I would be glad if you manage to deal with them!" He gives them the contact address written on his register. Go there.
801907: The diplomat simply states the crew need to find the owner of the ship stationed in the harbour. The harbour master seems to have information but is scared to give them.
801910: Give info, on the register an address is noted. Go there.
801912: The harbour master looks at the goods, clearly interested, but dismiss the proposal at once when he sees the so small amount the captain is ready to give away. "No sorry, I am not taking a risk for so little!"
801915: He is intimidated, give the address on the register. Go there.
801916: What an impressive display of strength! Shaking, the harbour master leads them to a house. "This it, now leave me out of it please!" and leaves at once.
801917: He is reassured, give the address on the register. Go there.
801918: "You are such good people, I ... I think I can trust you." He leads the crew to a house. "This is it, please do what needs to be done!" and he leaves at once in fear.
801919: A speech for the ages! The diplomat was lyrical, impressive in his description of the madness the Pyrphorian are capable of, emotional when he states what is at stake. The harbour master is clearly moved. "Oh if only we had more people ready to stand against evil like you do! It is my pleasure to help you." He leads them to a house. "This is it, I count on you." and leaves at once, visibly frighten he could be seen by the house occupants.
801920: Break the door open and rush in
801921: The crew uses a bench as a ram and break the door open. They storm in, sure to find a bunch of surprised Pyrphorian. Instead, they realize they were expected. The men are strong, armed, and ready to strike. The battle is harsh but fortunately the men didn't expect for the crew to be so numerous and strong. Crew has the upper hand but suffer from several injuries. Interrogate roughly a surviving attacker and learn they are from the local mafia, allied to the Pyrphorian and charged to take care of any nosey coming around.
801922: The sailors rush on the door at the same time, entending to break it with their shoulders. The only result is a few broken bones but a perfectly standing door. And the second attempt the door opens suddenly before they touch it, making a few sailors fall. They are immediately slained. Each sailor entering is met with a blow, clearly showing the men inside were well prepared for their arrival. The battle is unbalanced and quickly turn into a slaughter. One young sailor manages to escape while all his comrades are killed.
801924: Manage to sneak around the house discretely and enter through the back door. Once inside, while they were expecting a fairly empty house realize there is a lot of man patrolling in it, all very well armed, prepared around the front door for intruders entering. A trap! Fortunately their discretion gives the crew the upper hand and allows them to attack by surprise. The battle is harsh, the crew suffers from several injuries but they end up winning. Interrogate roughly a surviving attacker and learn they are from the local mafia, allied to the Pyrphorian and charged to take care of any nosey coming around.
801925: Not discrete, are noticed as soon as they try to enter the house. It is not a normal house, it is clearly filled to the roof of armed men, awaiting intruders. A trap! The battle is unbalanced and quickly turn into a slaughter. One young sailor manages to escape while all his comrades are killed.
801926: Spread the crew in the city, ear picking discretely for info
801927: Are spread and discretely occupy the space. Overhear conversations. One if particularly interesting about an unknown man who recently bought a magnificent orange house in the Placa district. Since buying it, the house is constantly guarded and visited by the strangest bunch. Go there.
801928: Do not hear anything of substance but are discrete enough to not have been noticed ear picking. Two sailors suggest to talk to people known for knowing everything about the city habitants: one sailor suggests to talk to the priest, with the confession they always know what nobody else knows. Another suggests to go to the brothel, it is known many secrets are shared when lying in bed.
801929: Go to the church and ask the priest help
801930: Priest see the faith the crew has and believe them when they say the Pyro are to be stopped for the greater good. Tell them that several of his flock have reported being worried about the visitors of a house in the Placa district, bought recently by a wealthy but anonymous man.
801931: Priest is glad to be able to help to crew. "God always help those who put faith in him!" He leads them to a house. "Many of my flock have told me about their fear of the people living there, a faithless organization devoted to evil spirits. It would be real blessing if you deliver us from them." He then leave at once, refusing to part in violence.
801932: Go to the brothel and ask for the prostitutes help
801933: Gladly help. Tell them some of their clients belong to a strange group gathering in a house in the Placa district. Their activities seemed suspicious but they were too proud of themselves not to discard some information about it. Go to the address.
801934: Refuse to help if you don't pay for the service. Time is money.
801935: Pay for the service and have the men behave
801936: Sailors are good guests. Not only pay their parts but also behave correctly. Once the hour ends the Madam decides to give the crew the info they are looking for. Some of their clients belong to a strange group gathering in a house in the Placa district. Their activities seemed suspicious but they were too proud of themselves not to discard some information about it. Go to the address.
801937: After an hour several bottles have been consumed, many words exchanged, the crew is having a great time. One prostitute then asks the crew to follow her to the house of one of her client. "He is part of a strange organization but he is too boastful to keep it for himself. I am sure they are the people you are looking for, they match in every way."
801940: Comply, seem afraid of what the crew might do. One prostitute asks the crew to follow her to the house of one of her client. "He is part of a strange organization but he is too boastful to keep it for himself. I am sure they are the people you are looking for, they match in every way."
801941: The crew waits and ear picks for hours but ears nothing. Couldn't handle it more, sailors starts to ask directly to people in the street if they know about the Pyrphorian. Luckily, after they gave a coin to two boys who promised they knew everything going on in the city they agree to lead them to a house where "a strange religious group" gathers often.
801943:
The young man succeeded in getting back to Izabel's island. In panic, he explains that his whole group was slaugthered. He was lucky enough to escape and managed to follow the murderers until he found the Pyrphorians' hide, a big house outside the city. A crew is assembled at once to go there.
The house and its grand French garden around it is seeable from the street but is surrounded by a high fence with two guards at the gate. Many guards are patrolling in the garden. Infiltrating the house won't be easy. Finding the contract there even less.
801944: Play it bold, launch a group assault on the house guards
801945: Attack the two guards at the door, kill them, take their keys and storm in, combat position. The guards are surprised and scattered, easier to get them now before they regroup.
801947:
Take one guard after the next before they have time to form a group and defend each others. In a few minute the beautiful white roses of French garden are painted red. The way to the house is free.
Inside the house, which room to look for?
801948:
Not good enough and fast enough to kill all the guards before they have a chance to regroup. Gathering their spirit they manage to put on a good defence before they are defeated. A few sailors are injured but they got the upper hand.
Inside the house, which room to look for?
801949: Take down the guards from a distance
801950:
Fall one after the other. In a few minutes it is silent again, the way to the house is free.
Inside the house, which room to look for?
801951:
Don't aim well enough. Most guards have time to regroup. Gathering their spirit they manage to put on a good defence before they are defeated. A few sailors are injured but they got the upper hand.
Inside the house, which room to look for?
801952: The crew storms at the two guards at the gate. However while the guards clearly benefited from military training, the crew is more disorganized. The guards manage to hold them just long enough for the reinforcement to regroup before falling, defeated. When the crew opens the gates the bulk of the troop is waiting for them, ready to harvest them.
801953: Let them pierce the crew centre group to surround them on the flanks
801954:
Marathon battle style. It works, the guards are defeated. A few sailors are injured but now the road to the house is open.
Inside the house, which room to look for?
801955:
A good military strategy is only good when well executed. This move cost more lives than if the un properly trained sailors had fight like they usually do, bar fight style. The battle lasts long and many good men are killed before the crew manages to finally get the upper hand. The road to the house is free but they must clearly act fast to find the contract before the reinforcement come.
Inside the house, which room to look for?
801956: Have the captain charge first, giving courage to all
801957:
Lord of the Ring style. The captain takes his swords and run toward the guards. The crew follows him and closes on the guards in a few seconds, as if animated by a divine push. The guards are defeated. A few sailors are injured but now the road to the house is open.
Inside the house, which room to look for?
801958:
Who did he think he was? Hero of ancient tales? At the first blow on their captain the crew conviction that they represent a greater good and will therefore be protected shatters. The battle is a bloodshed like many, nothing heroic about it. Many good men are killed before the crew manages to finally get the upper hand. The road to the house is free but they must clearly act fast to find the contract.
Inside the house, which room to look for?
801959: Play it sneaky, have the most discrete man go around the house
801960: Climb above the garden fence discreetly, manage to sneak around and find the kitchen door on the east aisle aside from the patrols. Unfortunately it is closed.
801961: Use the sword as a lever and push
801962:
Success, is in.
Inside the house, which room to look for?

801971: The man runs away and hides in a grove. A lot of guards are passing by.
801972: To be as effective as a shadow one must not simply need to move discretely but also pick the right path to do so. While discrete when climbing the fence, the man chose a too risky path and is forced to jump down in a grove. Many patrols are walking around him and it is now too dangerous to back track.
801973: Kill one of the guards and take his uniform

The man is quick and strong. Without having the time to scream or gasp of surprise the guards is on the floor. The man hides him in a grove and take his uniform. He can know walk into the house unsuspiciously.
